Ground Truth: ON Saturday, at the Croydon petty sessions, Percy Davis, alias Gordon, a clerk, and Robert Everett, alias Davenport (two fashionably-attired young men, of 47 Auckland-road, Vauxhall), and Elizabeth Williams described as a general servant, were charged on remand with being concerned together in stealing from the dwelling-house, 3 Prior-terrace, St. James's road, Croydon, since October 1881, two gold chains, two diamond rings, two cameo brooches, two gold seals, three gold pins, some silver forks and spoons, and about £20 in silver money, the property of Mary Ann Cosens, valued altogether at about £50; and Robert Everett, father of the prisoner of that name, was charged with receiving the property well knowing it to have been stolen, and he was further charged with unlawfully pledging the same.

Ground Truth: The last-named prisoner was for some years a superintendent in the Dorsetshire constabulary.

Ground Truth: Mr. Young, who appeared for the prosecution, said that his client, Mrs. Cosens, was an invalid lady eighty-two years of age, and quite unable to attend the court owing to her infirmity.

Ground Truth: He had evidently slept on the premises, and enticed the girl to steal her mistress's jewellery, which he took away and pledged, and spent the proceeds about the town; Everett shortly afterwards came upon the scene, and carried out the same kind of proceeding, Emily Barlow, cook to the prosecutrix, stated that the prisoners first came to the house in soldiers' clothes, which they afterwards exchanged for civilian dresses.

Ground Truth: AT the Widnes Police-court Peter O'Loughlin, son of a publican in Railway-street, Widnes, was charged with being drunk and disorderly in Anne-street East on Saturday night; also with assaulting Police-constable John Gamble, and with damaging his uniform to the extent of 2s. 6d.

Ground Truth: AN important case came on at the Gateshead County Police-court on Saturday, proceedings having been taken by the Home Office against the manager of the Usworth Colliery, for illegal shot-firing on March 2nd, the day on which the disastrous explosion, by which forty-two lives were lost, occurred at that colliery.

Ground Truth: The summons was issued against Mr. A. S. Palmer, who was present, as agent of the colliery.

OCR Text: be Mr. Mlorley said the prosecattion was taken under 35 1W and 36 Vie,, chap. 76, of thle Mines Boeglation Act.
Ground Truth: Mr. Morley said the prosecution was taken under 35 and 36 Vic., chap. 76, of the Mines Regulation Act.

OCR Text: ak With regard to thel use of gunpowdler, it was provided e that it slsoslld only be ned(l in cartridges, and not 'l0 within threnp months after any icflaminable gpo had Y. been foond in the mine.
Ground Truth: With regard to the use of gunpowder, it was provided that it should only be used in cartridges, and not within three months after any inflammable gas had been found in the mine.

OCR Text: The proseoution reliod iN this ro cage oui the faet that inllenmLblc gas had been foiund re in the miae within three inoatlis of the firing of the Ie shot, and the ((nostion wr9s Vhethler tbe regulatioi ic had been complied. with, it being requisite under the d, Act for some competent person duly appointed for id that purpipso to examine tlhe place where the shot was id to be fired immediately before the firing, and not to ar allow it to be discharged except it was safe to do eo.
Ground Truth: The prosecution relied in this case of the fact that inflammable gas had been found in the mine within three months of the firing of the shot, and the question was whether the regulation had been complied with, it being requisite under the Act for some competent person duly appointed for that purpose to examine the place where the shot was to be fired immediately before the firing, and not to allow it to be discharged except it was safe to do so.

OCR Text: 'B It was also provided that persons ordinarily employed s. in the mine were to be ont of it or that part of it g where the explosive wae to be used.
Ground Truth: It was also provided that persons ordinarily employed in the mine were to be out of it or that part of it where the explosive was to be used.

OCR Text: Mle, Ceoper said it be did not dismicte that gas lead been found, but it le was not fornd Within the conditions of the Act.
Ground Truth: Mr. Cooper said he did not dispute that gas had been found, but it was not found within the conditions of the Act.

Ground Truth: He was prepared to prove that it was due to a temporary stoppage in the ordinary ventilation appliances, and was removed when the ventilation was put right.

OCR Text: After evidence lad been given on bothe sides, it w-I 6S agreed between Mr. AMorley acd Mr. Cooper that thie g queestion at issue was really a legal one as to the mean L ing of the Act with regard to the cindlitions under wahich shot-firing should not talke place.
Ground Truth: After evidence had been given on both sides, it was agreed between Mr. Morley and Mr. Cooper that the question at issue was really a legal one as to the meaning of the Act with regard to the conditions under which shot-firing should not take place.

OCR Text: The Court. was, therefore, asked not to givo its decision, hit to adjourn the case until the legal question had bsen referredl to a superior court.
Ground Truth: The Court was, therefore, asked not to give its decision, but to adjourn the case until the legal question had been referred to a superior court.

OCR Text: The case was adjourned accordingly.
Ground Truth: The case was adjourned accordingly.

OCR Text: THE POISONING CASE IN FRASNCE.
Ground Truth: THE POISONING CASE IN FRANCE.

OCR Text: Tll. trial oi Peton tle doblu chlarge of poisoning his first wife--his second is still living-and a servant who was also his mistress, has resulted in a verdict of ty guilty agaiust the prisoner on the second count, or althougbh the jury were unable to makeup their minds at to convict him on the first, notwithstanding the de- of clared presence of arsenic in the exhumed remains of ts his wife.
Ground Truth: THE trial of Pel on the double charge of poisoning his first wife – his second is still living – and a servant who was also his mistress, has resulted in a verdict of guilty against the prisoner on the second count, although the jury were unable to make up their minds to convict him on the first, notwithstanding the declared presence of arsenic in the exhumed remains of his wife.

OCR Text: Altbough these weae the only two charges ig preferred against Pcl, he is ;lso suspected of having n poisoned his mother as long ago as 1872, and of saving )n attempted the lives, in a similar muaneor, of an old in woman named Miria Mahoin ann' a girl named Eg Xug6nio Meiyer, both of whom wore at different g times in 'el's service.
Ground Truth: Although these were the only two charges preferred against Pel, he is also suspected of having poisoned his mother as long ago as 1872, and of having attempted the lives, in a similar manner, of an old woman named Marie Mahoin and a girl named Eugénie Meyer, both of whom were at different times in Pel's service.

OCR Text: The girl aMeyer, indeed, as who freqauotly suffered from severe vomliting while aso she was in Pel's service, has never been seen since In Pet annoanced that she had left himi, and it was in asserted by the Public Prosecutor during the trial that re Pcl had poisened her and disposed of the body, as he ise is believed to havo disposed of that of Elise Blohliner, s- his servaut and umistrcss, whose case, therefore, is n- almost parallel witlh that of Eugp~uie Meyer.
Ground Truth: The girl Meyer, indeed, who frequently suffered from severe vomiting while she was in Pel's service, has never been seen since Pel announced that she had left him, and it was asserted by the Public Prosecutor during the trial that Pel had poisoned her and disposed of the body, as he is believed to have disposed of that of Elise Boehmer, his servant and mistress, whose case, therefore, is almost parallel with that of Eugénie Meyer.

OCR Text: It must Io be said that l',l'e eqplonation as to what had becomlie of the missing womvlen, and the cause of death of his 7, mother and first wife, were somewhat lame, and in although the evidence against him was almost entirely s, circumstantial, it is scarcely surprising that a verdict ry of guilty was entered.
Ground Truth: It must be said that Pel's explanation as to what had become of the missing women, and the cause of death of his mother and first wife, were somewhat lame, and although the evidence against him was almost entirely circumstantial, it is scarcely surprising that a verdict of guilty was entered.

OCR Text: There has, however, already mn been much comment on the fact that the prisoner was *st practically acquitted of tile charge agaiust his wife, th whose remains were found to contain poison, and con- ut victed of a charge of which absolutely no trace exists, as savo some cinders from the stove in which the victim's body is supposed to have becn burnt, and which are assumed to be all that remains of her icineratod corpso.
Ground Truth: There has, however, already been much comment on the fact that the prisoner was practically acquitted of the charge against his wife, whose remains were found to contain poison, and convicted of a charge of which absolutely no trace exists, save some cinders from the stove in which the victim's body is supposed to have been burnt, and which are assumed to be all that remains of her incinerated corpse.

OCR Text: M M. Henri Rlochefort, in the lJsrualsiyeuflnt, says that ~al tevriP a tho verdict against Pe1 is the first instance of a man a being found guilty of murder for poison when neither e the Ipisoe nor the victim's body hRs been found.
Ground Truth: M. Henri Rochefort, in the Intransigent, says that the verdict against Pel is the first instance of a man being found guilty of murder for poison when neither the poison nor the victim's body has been found.

OCR Text: La g Fr asnce calls attention to the lact that the jury gave a negative answer in the case of Pel's first wife, in whose remains distinct traces of arsenic woro discovered, and a an aflirmative answer in the indictment against the Y, prisoner for the murder of Eliso Boehiner, althoughl in n, the latter case the a cusaltion was only supported by rs medical conjedture.
Ground Truth: La France calls attention to the fact that the jury gave a negative answer in the case of Pel's first wife, in whose remains distinct traces of arsenic were discovered, and an affirmative answer in the indictment against the prisoner for the murder of Elise Boehmer, although in the latter case the accusation was only supported by medical conjecture.

OCR Text: Lro Franca also calls attention to nt the lamentable defenco that wasv made on the prisoner's ce beihalf.
Ground Truth: La France also calls attention to the lamentable defence that was made on the prisoner's behalf.

OCR Text: The Figaro thanks the jury for having reso- Id lutely saved society fromill le possible repetition of re similar crimes by bringing in a verdict of guilty.
Ground Truth: The Figaro thanks the jury for having resolutely saved society from the possible repetition of similar crimes by bringing in a verdict of guilty.

OCR Text: Pes m had been removed to the condemned cell at La Iloquette 3d prison
Ground Truth: Pel had been removed to be condemned cell at La Roquette prison.

OCR Text: Shine his coviction Put has displayed more ot enmotion, and continues to earnestly declare his Joo- re cence.
Ground Truth: Since his conviction Pel has displayed more emotion and continues to earnestly declare his innocence.

Ground Truth: Pell has been sentenced to death.

OCR Text: -In this case a rule had been granted for a certiorari to remove an indictment for libel preferred against George Francis Legg, a solicitor, on the prosecution of Harold Alexander, an officer in her Majesty's army, from the Central Criminal Court to this Court, in order that it might be tried before a special jury.
Ground Truth: – In this case a rule had been granted for a certiorari to remove an indictment for libel preferred against George Francis Legg, a solicitor, on the prosecution of Harold Alexander, an officer in her Majesty's army, from the Central Criminal Court to this Court, in order that it might be tried before a special jury.

OCR Text: The circumstances were as follow: Both the defendant and prosecutor are members of the Cocoa Tree Club, in St. James'-street, Piccadilly, and on the 8th of December, 1884, they played at cards there the result being that Mr. Alexander won �1,760 from Mr. Legg, who, as he was losing, said he would only lose �500, which he was ready at once to nay, provided that any sum exceeding that amount should be played for on a future evening.
Ground Truth: The circumstances were as follow: Both the defendant and prosecutor are members of the Cocoa Tree Club, in St. James'-street, Piccadilly, and on the 8th of December, 1884, they played at cards there the result being that Mr. Alexander won £1,760 from Mr. Legg, who, as he was losing, said he would only lose £500, which he was ready at once to pay, provided that any sum exceeding that amount should be played for on a future evening.

OCR Text: They subse- quently played a few games, when Mr. Alexander won at. additional �200, and the defendant paid him -�500, the balance standing over.
Ground Truth: They subsequently played a few games, when Mr. Alexander won an additional £200, and the defendant paid him £500, the balance standing over.

OCR Text: A few weeks afterwards Mr. Legg, according to his affidavit, heard that Mr. Alex- ander had been accused of cheating a Mr. Wyndham of �550 at cards; at the Road Club, in January, 1885, and on the 18th of February the defendant wrote a letter to the committee of the Cocoa Tree Club to the effect that Mr. Harold Alexander had been com- pelled to resign his membership of the Road Club, having been detected at cheating at cards, and that he was prepared to prove this charge.
Ground Truth: A few weeks afterwards Mr. Legg, according to his affidavit, heard that Mr. Alexander had been accused of cheating a Mr. Wyndham of £550 at cards, at the Road Club, in January, 1885, and on the 18th of February the defendant wrote a letter to the committee of the Cocoa Tree Club to the effect that Mr. Harold Alexander had been compelled to resign his membership of the Road Club, having been detected at cheating at cards, and that he was prepared to prove this charge.

OCR Text: This was the libel complained of, and for which he was committed for trial, but was allowed to stand out on his own recog. nisanees of �50.
Ground Truth: This was the libel complained of, and for which he was committed for trial, but was allowed to stand out on his own recognisances of £50.

OCR Text: The matter now came before this court on an application by Mr. Matthews, which was opposed by Mr. Gill, to expedite the hearing of the rule for the certiorari, in order that the' trial might. take place before the prosecutor had to rejoin his regi. ment in India.
Ground Truth: The matter now came before this court on an application by Mr. Matthews, which was opposed by Mr. Gill, to expedite the hearing of the rule for the certiorari, in order that the trial might take place before the prosecutor had to rejoin his regiment in India.

OCR Text: The Court, disapproving of the course taken by the prosecutor in instituting criminal pro- ceodings in the case of a private squabble, refused the application'with costs.
Ground Truth: The Court, disapproving of the course taken by the prosecutor in instituting criminal proceedings in the case of a private squabble, refused the application with costs.

OCR Text: s r T JOHN DAVIES, of Lansdown-place, Brunswick-square, an ironmonger, George Denny Ruck, alias Foster, a clerk, of Paradise-street, Lambeth, and John Jack- son, a traveller, of Braden-street, Maida Vale, were charged on remand at the Marlborough-street Police- court, on Saturday, with conspiring to obtain various sums of money.
Ground Truth: JOHN DAVIES, of Lansdown-place, Brunswick-square, an Ironmonger, George Denny Ruck, alias Foster, a clerk, of Paradise-street, Lambeth, and John Jackson, a traveller, of Braden-street, Maida Vale, were charged on remand at the Marlborough-street Police-court, on Saturday, with conspiring to obtain various sums of money.

OCR Text: Three cases have already been in- vestigated against the accused,
Ground Truth: Three cases have already been in vestigated against the accused.

Ground Truth: He left the office, but returned again the same day, when he saw Davies.

Ground Truth: He was informed that expenses would be incurred in making inquiries, and was asked for a guines, which he paid.

Ground Truth: No money was ever advanced to him by the prisoners.

Ground Truth: She was asked for a fee of 10s. 6d. "for inquiries," which she paid, and she also deposited the lease of her house and gave two references.

OCR Text: I ATTEMPTED MURDER AT STAMFORD HILL.
Ground Truth: ATTEMPTED MURDER AT STAMFORD HILL.

OCR Text: ON Saturday night an extraordinary and apparently deliberate attempt to murder a woman, the wife of a house and estate agent named Tomlinson, of 7, Champion-terrace, Stamford Hill, took place in the public thoroughfare, about one hundred yards dis- tance from her residence.
Ground Truth: ON Saturday night an extraordinary and apparently deliberate attempt to murder a woman, the wife of a house and estate agent named Tomlinson, of 7, Champion-terrace, Stamford Hill, took place in the public thoroughfare, about one hundred yards' distance from her residence.

OCR Text: She left home at twenty minutes past nine for the purpose of making a few purchases, and was almost immediated accosted by a man from behind.
Ground Truth: She left home at twenty minutes past nine for the purpose of making a few purchases, and was almost immediated accosted by a man from behind.

OCR Text: She turned round at once, and found that it was her sister's husband, William Eiworthy.
Ground Truth: She turned round at once, and found that it was her sister's husband, William Esworthy.

OCR Text: He walked by her side for a second or two, and then suddenly fired a pistol at the back of her head.
Ground Truth: He walked by her side for a second or two, and then suddenly fired a pistol at the back of her head.

OCR Text: She secreamed. "Murder; I am shot i and fell to the ground insensible.
Ground Truth: She screamed, "Murder; I am shot!" and fell to the ground insensible.

OCR Text: A'girl living on the spot ran across the road and recognised Mrs. Tomlinson as she lay bleeding on the pavement.
Ground Truth: A girl living on the spot ran across the road and recognised Mrs. Tomlinson as she lay bleeding on the pavement.

OCR Text: Being Saturday night there were many people about.
Ground Truth: Being Saturday night there were many people about.

OCR Text: A crowdsoon assembled, and the. injured woman having been car- ried into her own house, Dr. Duncan, of Amherst Park, was sent for.
Ground Truth: A crowd soon assembled, and the injured woman having been carried into her own house, Dr. Duncan, of Amherst Park, was sent for.

OCR Text: He soon arrived, and found her suffering from a bullet wound behind the right ear, but the bullet had not penetrated the skull, having bounded off after striking the bone.
Ground Truth: He soon arrived, and found her suffering from a bullet wound behind the right ear, but the bullet had not penetrated the skull, having bounded off after striking the bone.

OCR Text: Search was subsequently made for the bullet, but it could not be found.
Ground Truth: Search was subsequently made for the bullet, but it could not be found.

OCR Text: After the woman fell Esworthy hurried to the opposite side of the street, and threw something over a fence.
Ground Truth: After the woman fell Esworthy hurried to the opposite side of the street, and threw something over a fence.

OCR Text: He had been seen to fire the pistol by some passers by, and was seized by several men, who took him towards the Stoke Newington Police-station.
Ground Truth: He had been seen to fire the pistol by some passers by, and was seized by several men, who took him towards the Stoke Newington Police-station.

OCR Text: They were met, however, by Sergeant Collins, of the N Division, to whom they reported the circumstances of the case, and gave the man into his custody.
Ground Truth: They were met, however, by Sergeant Collins, of the N Division, to whom they reported the circumstances of the case, and gave the man into his custody.

OCR Text: Collins, accompanied by a great many persons, conveyed Esworthy to the Tottenham Police-station.
Ground Truth: Collins, accompanied by a great many persons, conveyed Esworthy to the Tottenham Police-station.

OCR Text: There he was charged with "shooting and wounding with intent to murder one Harriet Tomlinson, at the High-road, Stamford Hill. In the parieh of Tottenham."
Ground Truth: There he was charged with "shooting and wounding with intent to murder one Harriet Tomlinson, at the High-road, Stamford Hill, in the parish of Tottenham."

OCR Text: He gave the name of William Esworthy, ngedtwenty-eight, address 29, South-street, Manchester-square; business, commis- sion agent.
Ground Truth: He gave the name of William Esworthy, aged twenty-eight, address 29, South-street, Manchester-square; business, commission agent.

OCR Text: On the charge being read over to him he remarked, "She did it herself, and I took the revolver away from her, and threw it over a fence on the opposite side of the road."
Ground Truth: On the charge being read over to him he remarked, "She did it herself, and I took the revolver away from her, and threw it over a fence on the opposite side of the road."

OCR Text: On being searched a few coins and a cleaning-rod of a pistol was found upon him, but no ammunition.
Ground Truth: On being searched a few coins and a cleaning-rod of a pistol was found upon him, but no ammunition.

OCR Text: The prisoner having been locked up, Inspector Ashwell and Sergeant Collins proceeded to the spot Indicated by him to search for the revolver; but, after a close inspec- tion for an hour or so, they had not succeeded in finding it,
Ground Truth: The prisoner having been locked up, Inspector Ashwell and Sergeant Collins proceeded to the spot indicated by him to search for the revolver; but, after a close inspection for an hour or so, they had not succeeded in finding it.

OCR Text: The search then discontinued; it was re- sumed on Sunday morning at daylight by Sergeant Collins, and at a quarter-past five o'clock he dis- covered the revolver in a builder's yard, almost opposite where the crime was committed.
Ground Truth: The search then discontinued; it was resumed on Sunday morning at daylight by Sergeant Collins, and at a quarter past five o'clock he discovered the revolver in a builder's yard, almost opposite where the crime was committed.

OCR Text: It is a weapon with seven chambers, six of which were loaded when It was picked up.
Ground Truth: It is a weapon with seven chambers, six of which were loaded when it was picked up.

OCR Text: It was, therefore, fully charged when the attack was made upon Mrs. Tomlinson.
Ground Truth: It was, therefore, fully charged when the attack was made upon Mrs. Tomlinson.

Ground Truth: In investigating the matter on Sunday the police ascertained that the prisoner spent nearly the whole of Saturday afternoon and evening watching the playing of cricket on some vacant land at the rear of Champion-terrace.

Ground Truth: After the match was over he was seen to pass Tomlinson's place of business and go to a public-house, where he had some whisky.

Ground Truth: He then repassed the shop, and evidently waited about in the expectation that Mrs. Tomlinson would come out, as she eventually did, to make Saturday night's purchases.

OCR Text: Mrs. Tom- linson, is the mother of two children, and is much respected by her neighbours, who express great sym- pathy towards her in her suffering, and make anxious inquiries as to her condition,
Ground Truth: Mrs. Tomlinson, is the mother of two children, and is much respected by her neighbours, who express great sympathy towards her in her suffering, and make anxious inquiries as to her condition.

OCR Text: It is clear that she had a miraculous escape from death.
Ground Truth: It is clear that she had a miraculous escape from death.

OCR Text: As it is she is badly wounded, and her system has received a very severe shock, but there is scarcely any fear of her ultimate recovery.
Ground Truth: As it is she is badly wounded, and her system has received a very severe shock, but there is scarcely any fear of her ultimate recovery.

OCR Text: On Sunday evening the symp- toms were highly favourable to that view.
Ground Truth: On Sunday evening the symptoms were highly favourable to that view.

OCR Text: As may be imagined, the affair, happening in a crowded thoroughfare at a busy time on Saturday night, created intense excitement.
Ground Truth: Ae may be imagined, the affair, happening in a crowded thoroughfare at a busy time on Saturday night, created intense excitement.

OCR Text: Prisoner will be taken before the magistrates at Edmonton in a day or two.
Ground Truth: Prisoner will be taken before the magistrates at Edmonton in a day or two.

Ground Truth: Last week, however, he committed suicide by hanging, and Mr. Holmes Moss (solicitor) read the following letter he had received from the accused: - "Point Hill House, July 9th, 1889. Man is the greatest enemy man has got. If the police would try to prevent crime instead of laying traps to create it, there would not be one half the misery in the world there is. £ s. d. is the god of all classes, parsons not excepted. Ground Truth: The letter was as follows: - "My Lord, - I am a very young widow, and was married at eighteen. My husband died in India a fortnight after our marriage. I was in India a short time. My annuity, though not large, is sufficient for my wants; but it will not bear the strain of another's debts. Hence my writing to your lordship. I became security for an aged gentlewoman, and she cannot pay. I am tall and graceful, with a perfect figure, and in features am like the Princess of Wales. My house is large, well appointed, in the best part of Oxford; and your lordship could come to me as often as you liked, without anyone knowing it. All I ask is £50-a part now and a part at other times. But, above all things, preserve secrecy, as I am highly connected, and have a position to keep up. This writing is intentionally formal, and not my current Italian hand. I am very young. -I have the honour to be, my lord, your lordship's obedient servant, M."

I am sure all will be right in the end."

Ground Truth: It was the opinion of almost every one acquainted with the fact that, if the prisoner had been put upon his trial on the present occasion, he must have been acquitted, in which case he would have been altogether relieved from the charge, but by the course that has been taken, if any evidence should be obtained at a future time to confirm the evidence of the woman Page, it will still be competent to try him for the murder, so that it is not at all improbable that the interests of justice will still be vindicated in reference to this fearful crime.

OCR Text: The two young men were nct suspected ot participation in the moneys appropriated by Salmon, but were nevertheless convicted of the offence charged, and were each sentenced to two years' imprisonment.
Ground Truth: The two young men were not suspected of participation in the money appropriated by Salmon, but were nevertheless convicted of the offence charged, and were each sentenced to two years' imprisonment.

Ground Truth: The representations made ot the home secretary, however, succeeded in procuring the liberation of both at or before the expiry of six months.

Ground Truth: PROGRESS OF REFORM.

OCR Text: I,We are in a position to state that the organiation conducted by the Parliamentary Reform committee has greatly strengthened itself by adherents from all raks since the recent conference at the Gaildball coffee-house.
Ground Truth: We are in a position to state that the organisation conducted by the Parliamentary Reform committee has greatly strengthened itself by adherents from all ranks since the recent conference at the Guildhall coffee-house.

OCR Text: Several additions have been made to the committee, and subscriptions for large and small *amounts continue to flow iuto the trasur.
Ground Truth: Several additions have been made to the committee, and subscriptions for large and small amounts continue to flow into the treasury.

OCR Text: A remout circular, which has been extensively distributed, Nstaten:- "The success of this movement must depend on the support it receives from the country. The committee, although they adopted as the result of exten. aire inquiries their published programme, as likely to be sanctioned by the largest number of constituent -bodies, do not preoscribe it to any as the basis of thedror. ganisatlon. They are especially anxious that reformers wShould place themselves in the mocst advantageous poitien to pronounce on any R~eform bill which may beintrodluced into parliament, as to how far it fairly complies with the people's reasonable demands, liitherto their wrk, which has not been unproduc" tive, has been accomplished at a very moderate outlay; but the time has clearly arrived when a bolder attitude must he taken, and without any elaborate agitation they must be prepared for a very large additional expenditure. Their efforts will necessarily be limited by the means placed at their disposal, and they respectfully solicit co-operation in their endea-yours to render the EHuse of Commons truly representative of the people."
Ground Truth: A recent circular, which has been extensively distributed, states: -- "The success of this movement must depend on the support it receives from the country. The committee, although they adopted as the result of extensive inquiries their published programme, as likely to be sanctioned by the largest number of constituent bodies, do not prescribe it to any as the basis of their organisation. They are especially anxious that reformers should place themselves in the most advantageous position to pronounce on any Reform bill which may be introduced into parliament, as to how far it fairly complies with the people's reasonable demands, Hitherto their work, which has not been unproductive, has been accomplished at a very moderate out lay; but the time has clearly arrived when a bolder attitude must be taken, and without any elaborate agitation they must be prepared for a very large additional expenditure. Their efforts will necessarily be limited by the means placed at their disposal, and they respectfully solicit co-operation in their endeavors to render the House of Commons truly representative of the people."

OCR Text: -A fearful tra&edy was enacted yesterday morning at the town of Lydney, on the South Wales railway, between this city and Chepstow.
Ground Truth: -A fearful tragedy was enacted yesterday morning at the town of Lydney, on the South Wales railway, between this city and Chepstow.

OCR Text: It appears that an elderly gentleman, of the name of Pownall, a retired physician and a native of Wroughton,, Wilts, has been residing with Mr. Leete, surgeon, of Lydney, for the last three weeks.
Ground Truth: It appears that an elderly gentleman, of the name of Pownall, a retired physician and a native of Wroughton, Wilts, has been residing with Mr. Leete, surgeon, of Lydney, for the last three weeks.

OCR Text: lRe had formerly heen an inmate of Northwood's asylum, nesr Bristol, hut had recently been dis- charged as cured, with a certificate to that effect from Dr. Davoy, the medical superintendent.
Ground Truth: He had formerly been an inmate of Northwood's asylum, near Bristol, but had recently boon discharged as cured, with a certificate to that effect from Dr. Davey, the medical superintendent.

OCR Text: During his residence at Lydney he has been quiet and gentle- manly in his habits and conduct, and has never shown any symptoms of unsoundness of mind.
Ground Truth: During his residence at Lydney he has been quiet and gentlemanly in his habits and conduct, and has never shown any symptoms of unsoundness of mind.

OCR Text: About six o'clock yesterday morning he knocked at the servants' bed room door, and called them up.
Ground Truth: About six o'clock yesterday morning he knocked at the servants' bed room door, and called them up.

OCR Text: One of them (a girl named Louisa Cook, aged fifteen years) dressed herself quickly, and went out.
Ground Truth: One of them (a girl named Louisa Cook, aged fifteen years) dressed herself quickly, and went out.

OCR Text: In a mi- nute or two the other girl, who bad not risen, heard a scuffle on the stairs, and cries of " Marder !"
Ground Truth: In a minute or two the other girl, who had not risen, heard a scuffle on the stairs, and cries of "Murder!"

OCR Text: She got up and looked out, but could see nothing; and having called out, " What is the matter?" received no answer.
Ground Truth: She got up and looked out, but could see nothing; and having called out, "What is the matter?" received no answer.

OCR Text: She returned into the room to dress her- self, leaving the door partly open, and in a minute or two Dr. Pownall, in his shirt sleeves, looked into the room. and said, "Make haste; get assistance; some one has murdered her ," and then retired to his own room, locking the door.
Ground Truth: She returned into the room to dress herself, leaving the door partly open, and in a minute or two Dr. Pownall, in his shirt sleeves, looked into the room, and said, "Make haste; get assistance; someone has murdered her" and then retired to his own room, locking the door.

OCR Text: Sergeant Pope, of the po- lice, was immediately called in, and on going to Mr. Leete's bed room, he found the poor girl, Cooke, ly- ing dead upon the floor, with a fearful wound in her throat, from which a large quantity of blood had flowed.
Ground Truth: Sergeant Pope, of the police, was immediately called in, and ongoing to Mr. Leete's bed room, he found the poor girl, Cooke, lying dead upon the floor, with a fearful wound in her throat, from which a large quantity of blood had flowed.

OCR Text: The poor girl had rushed into the room, ex- claiming, "Master, he has murdered me; I mast die ;" having repeated which two or three times, she fell down dead.
Ground Truth: The poor girl had rushed into the room, exclaiming, "Master, he has murdered me; I must die;" having repented which two or three times, she fell down dead.

OCR Text: Dr. Pownall was immediately ap. prehended, and submitted quietly.
Ground Truth: Dr. Pownall was immediately apprehended, and submitted quietly.

Ground Truth: An inquest was held last night at the Feathers hotel, Lydney, the Rev. H. Philpot, the vicar, acting as foreman of the jury.

Ground Truth: Mary Ann Fryer, fellow servant of the deceased, and the policeman Pope, having deposed to the above facts.

Ground Truth: Dr. Pownall, who had not hitherto spoken, but sat at the table shading his eyes with his hands, said slowly and in a deep voice, "I can tell you I unfortunately did it. I can hardly assign any motive. I felt I was bound to do something, and I could not resist it."

Ground Truth: Mr. Charles Lydiat Leete deposed: I am a surgeon, residing at Lydney, and decensed was in my service.

Ground Truth: This morning she rushed into my bedroom with her throat cut, and died in a few minutes.

Ground Truth: When she came in she exclaimed, "Master, he has murdered me; I must die."

Ground Truth: He has been residing with me that time.

OCR Text: He has all along appeared sane and rea- sonable, and I saw no change in him when I parted from him last night.
Ground Truth: He has all along appeared sane and reasonable, and I saw no change in him when I parted from him last night.

OCR Text: He showed me a certificate from Dr. Davey, which certified that he left his lunatic asylum cured.
Ground Truth: He showed me a certificate from Dr. Davey, which certified that he left his lunatic asylum cured.

Ground Truth: On Wednesday morning, the jury met to resume their inquiry at the New Globe tavern, Bow-road, into the death of an infant, about three weeks old, named Philip Yorath, illegitimate child of Miss Elizabeth Yorath, sister of a highly respectable surgeon of that name, practising at Newport, in Monmouthshire.

Ground Truth: The investigation arose in consequence of several anonymous letters forwarded to the Bishop of London, signed "A Parishioner," reflecting on the moral conduct of the Rev. J. Bonwell, rector of St. Philip's district church, Stepney, residing with his wife in Thornhill square, Islington, where Mrs. Bonwell carries on a ladies' school.

OCR Text: The anonymous letters con- tained grave charges against the rev. gentleman, which charges have already been given in our previous report.
Ground Truth: The anonymous letters contained grave charges against the rev. gentleman, which charges have already been given in our previous report.

OCR Text: The inquest was opened on Saturday, the 17th of September, when evidence was taken of the burial of Elizabeth Acock by Ayres, on Sunday, the 4th of September, the exhumation of the body, and the finding of the infant, and the inquiry was accordingly adjourned for the production of the necessary wit- nesses, and to give time for the analysis of the intes- tines of the infant, whose death and burial were of so mysterious a character.
Ground Truth: The inquest was opened on Saturday, the 17th of September, when evidence was taken of the burial of Elizabeth A cock by Ayres, on Sunday, the 4th of September, the exhumation of the body, and the finding of the infant, and the inquiry was accordingly adjourned for the production of the necessary witnesses, and to give time for the analysis of the intestines of the infant, whose death and burial were of so mysterious a character.

OCR Text: The jury reassembled on Wednesday morning, and proceeded to hear evidence relative to this extraordi. nary, painful, and delicate case.
Ground Truth: The jury re-assembled on Wednesday morning, and proceeded to hear evidence relative to this extraordinary, painful, and delicate case.

Ground Truth: The Rev. Mr. Lee, rector of Stepney, and several other clergy men were present.

Ground Truth: The names of the jurymen having been called over, Dr. Challice said: In this case Mr. Humphreys, the coroner, having commenced the proceedings, I am sorry to say he is in that state of health that it is im possible for him to attend to-day, and under the circumstances 1 must adjourn the court.

Ground Truth: Mr. Best, barrister, instructed by Mr. J. B. Sorrell, of No. 60, Mark-lane, who attended to watch the proceedings on behalf of the Rev. J. Bonwell, vehemently protested against the postponement.

Ground Truth: On Thursday, Alfred Harris and Joseph Stanfield, a couple of lads in the employ of Messrs. Smith and Co., whip makers, of Beech street, Barbican, were charged, at the Guildhall police-court, with robbing their employers of goods to the value of nearly 100l., and Joseph Taylor was charged with feloniously receiving the property knowing it to have been stolen.

OCR Text: The detective officers Bull and Baker stated that they were in Beech-street, Barbican, about one o'clock in the day, on the 30th July, when they saw the prisoners leaving the prosecutor's premises, and they followed them to Golden lane, and then stopped them.
Ground Truth: The detective officers Bull and Baker stated that they were in Beech-street, Barbican, about one o'clock in the day, on the 30th July, when they saw the prisoners leaving the prosecutor's premises, and they followed them to Golden lane, and then stopped them.

OCR Text: On Stanfield, Baker found forty-two German silver whip mounts, and on Harris, Bull found twventy-four similar whip mounts.
Ground Truth: On Stanfield, Baker found forty-two German silver whip mounts, and on Harris, Bull found twenty-four similar whip mounts.

OCR Text: Baker then went to 54, Coppice-row, Clerkenwell, where he found Taylor, who had formerly been in the prosecutor's service.
Ground Truth: Baker then went to 54, Coppice-row, Clerkenwell, where he found Taylor, who had formerly been in the prosecutor's service.

OCR Text: Taylor admitted having bought a quantity of goods of Stanfield, and said he had sold a portion of them to a Mr. Schomberg, of the Sonthwarkbridge-road.
Ground Truth: Taylor admitted having bought a quantity of goods of Stanfield, and said he had sold a portion of them to a Mr. Schomberg, of the Southwark bridge-road.

OCR Text: At Taylor's house, Baker found fifteen buck whistles, six stag horn hooks, five pig hooks, twienty-six small buck hooks, and nine sets of walking stick mounts.
Ground Truth: At Taylor's house, Baker found fifteen buck whistles, six stag horn hooks, five pig hooks, twenty-six small buck hooks, and nine sets of walking stick mounts.

OCR Text: He also said he had bought two or three lots of buck hooks for 2s. or 3s.
Ground Truth: He also said he had bought two or three lots of buck hooks for 2s. or 3s.

OCR Text: Some of the prosecutor's property was found at Schomberg'-s.
Ground Truth: Some of the prosecutor's property was found at Schomberg's.

OCR Text: When Bull accused Harris of robbing his masters he said he had been led into itby Stanfield and Taylor.
Ground Truth: When Bull accused Harris of robbing his masters he said he had been led into it by Stanfield and Taylor.

OCR Text: William Shrosbree, a workuman in Messrs. Smith's employ, said he saw Stanfield come out of the stockroom about three months ago with some whip mounts, which, he said, he was going to take to Taylor.
Ground Truth: William Shrosbree, a workman in Messrs. Smith's employ, said he saw Stanfield come out of the stock room about three months ago with some whip mounts, which, he said, he was going to take to Taylor.

OCR Text: Witness tried to persuade him to put them back, and on the following morning Ile said he had taken them to Taylor.
Ground Truth: Witness tried to persuade him to put them back, and on the following morning he said he had taken them to Taylor.

Ground Truth: Witness did not tell his masters then, because he thought Stanfield would not do it again.

OCR Text: Mr. Schomberg said he paid Taylor at the rate of 7s. per dozen for the buckhorn whistles and hooks, and Se. per dozen for the mounts.
Ground Truth: Mr. Schomberg said he paid Taylor at the rate of 7s. per dozen for the buckhorn whistles and hooks, and 8s. per dozen for the mounts.

OCR Text: Taylor told him he brought them from Birmingham.
Ground Truth: Taylor told him he brought them from Birmingham.

OCR Text: Mr. Smith identified the articles produced as his property, and further said that on the morning of the 1Oth July he was secreted on his premises, and from his place of concealment saw Stanfield force open a door leading to the warehouse.
Ground Truth: Mr. Smith identified the articles produced as his property, and further said that on the morning of the 30th July he was secreted on his premises, and from his place of concealment saw Stanfield force open a door leading to the warehouse.

OCR Text: The Sltio Jadreae4deet thus describes the last scene :-" It was 7.45 o'01ock when he stepped out before the public gaze of assembled thousands, who occupied every available point of view far and near, and gazed anxiously with upturned eyes expecting his appearance. The hum of the excited crowd rose from below, not unlike the noise of a distant waterfall; most instantly the treacherous bars on which the condemned stood swiftly and noiselessly gave way, and he descended like an arrow shot from a bow for a distance of seven or eight feet, the weight of his body making a sickening, deadened sort of sound as he suddenly reached the length of the rope. The fail itself must have killed him. Aftera few convulsive struggles, of which he was quite unconscious, all was over, Matthew Phibbs was dead. Having hung the usual length of time, his dead body was withdrawn from the public gaze, and buried within the precincts of the prison, in accordance with the sentence of the cour.t Dr. Lynn inspected the body, and officially reported it dead. It has been estimated that about 10,000 people witnessed the execution. Their conduct was orderly and becoming in a remarkable degree. There were 150 constabulary on the ground before the scaffold under the charge of Cap. tain Stoker, Sub-inspectors Neynoe and Vallancy, Head-constable O'Donnell, &e. Many of the crowd remained until the body was cut down and placed in its coffin outside the gaol door, after which all dispersed quietly and orderly their several ways."

The fall itself must have killed him. After a few convulsive struggles, of which he was quite unconscious, all was over, Matthew Phibbs was dead. There were 150 constabulary on the ground before the scaffold under the charge of Captain Steker, Sub-inspectors Neynoe and Vallancy, Head-constable O'Donnell, &c. Many of the crowd remained until the body was cut down and placed in its coffin outside the gaol door, after which all dispersed quietly and orderly their several ways."

She muttered something %vhibh I could not hear, end I couild nottelwash ,id. r said to her;I A'ny ways, you will suffer for this;. stisi ot the first or second time you served me to ' 'Whilezihe was trying to light the fire I got out of' teamperand struck her, when she fell, and I kicked tier with my foot, and I think that the heel of my Iboot must have made a gash in her head and caused her death.' Ground Truth: The prisoner said he wished to make a statement, and I wrote down as follows. - "The deceased Sarah Scott has lived with me at 3, White's-grounds four years. Her husband died four years ago. On Saturday evening we had no dispute. When I came in I saw she was the worse for liquor, and that there was no fire. I said, 'Why don't you get my tea?' She muttered something which I could not hear, and I could not tell what she said. I said to her, 'Any ways, you will suffer for this; 'tis not the first or second time you served me so.' While she was trying to light the fire I got out of temper and struck her, when she fell, and I kicked her with my foot, and I think that the heel of my boot must have made a gash in her head and caused her death. I then went into the yard, and when I came again into the house I found she had not moved. I lifted her up and found that she was insensible. I found life was gone from her. I laid her head on a small block of wood and sent fora doctor by my next door neighbour. I fancy she was led away by Mrs. Lapthorne, living at No. 2, White's grounds. The deceased had two children by her husband."

Ground Truth: SERIOUS CHARGE OF FRAUD.

OCR Text: On Wednesday, Thomas Payne, a mhan of highly' respectable appearance, surrendered at the Surrey sessions in discharge of his bail, to answer an indict' meat charging hime with, being bailee of a certain quantity of wh'eat, having sold an d converted the proceeds to his own Use in fraud of the London, Brighton, and South Coast railway company.
Ground Truth: On Wednesday, Thomas Payne, a man of highly respectable appearance, surrendered at the Surrey sessions in discharge of his bail, to answer an indictment charging him with, being bailee of a certain quantity of wheat, having sold and converted the proceeds to his own use in fraud of the London, Brighton, and South Coast railway company.

OCR Text: In other counts, the property was laid variously as being that of the consigner and consigne.
Ground Truth: In other counts, the property was laid variously as being that of the consigner and consignee.

OCR Text: -Thaprisonerpleadednot guilty.
Ground Truth: -The prisoner pleaded not guilty.

OCR Text: The facts of the case appeared to be these.
Ground Truth: The facts of the case appeared to be these.

OCR Text: The prisoner had been the proprietor of the Goat Bouse hotel, at South Norwood, and he let some portion of his premises to two persons, named Franks and Gander, who painted up the firm of "Franks and Co., corn and flour factors."
Ground Truth: The prisoner had been the proprietor of the Goat House hotel, at South Norwood, and he let some portion of his premises to two persons, named Franks and Gander, who painted up the firm of "Franks and Co., corn and flour factors."

OCR Text: On the 5th Decembet last it appears that forty-six quarters of wheat had been purchased from a Mr. Flexman, of Watford, by a Mr. Harradance, a corn merchant, carrying on business at the Corn exchange, Mark-lane, and residing at Lower Norwood.
Ground Truth: On the 5th December last it appears that forty-six quarters of wheat had been purchased from a Mr. Flexman, of Watford, by a Mr. Harradance, a corn merchant, carrying on business at the Corn exchange, Mark-lane, and residing at Lower Norwood.

OCR Text: The instructions given by the buyer were that the whole should be forwarded to the Wakefield corn market. but by mistake they were sent on to the Norwood Junction station in two trucks, and there the property arrived on the 12th Deceniber, with a consign. ment note to Mr. Harradance, who having only a private residence there wvas not known as a corn merchant.
Ground Truth: The instructions given by the buyer were that the whole should be forwarded to the Wakefield corn market but by mistake they were sent on to the Norwood Junction station in two trucks, and there the property arrived on the 12th December, with a consignment note to Mr. Harradance, who having only a private residence there was not known as a corn merchant.

OCR Text: On the 14th December, in consequenceof the alleaed consignee not being found, Mr. Harold BriLdger, the superinten dent of the goods department at the Norwood Junction station, set out to make inquiries, and calling on -the prisoner at his hotel, asked him if he knew Mr. Harradance, as there were somne goods awaiting for him at the station.
Ground Truth: On the 14th December, in consequence of the alleged consignee not being found, Mr. Harold Bridger, the superintendent of the goods department at the Norwood Junction station, set out to make inquiries, and calling on the prisoner at his hotel, asked him if he knew Mr. Harradance, as there were some goods waiting for him at the station.

OCR Text: In a few days afterwards the prisoner presented himself at the goods station, and claimed the goods for the firm of "Franks and Co.," and paid the amount of carriage of the goods, 1?. 19s. lld., and not only directed the wheat to be conveyed to the stores of the supposed firm of Franks and Co., but actuafly superintended the loading- of the carts, and the deposit of the wheat into the stores.
Ground Truth: In a few days afterwards the prisoner presented himself at the goods station, and claimed the goods for the firm of "Franks and Co.," and paid the amount of carriage of the goods, 1l. 19s. 11d., and not only directed the wheat to be conveyed to the stores of the supposed firm of Franks and Co., but actually superintended the loading of the carts, and the deposit of the wheat into the stores.

OCR Text: In consequence of the loss of the wheat further investigation ensued, and this continued until February last, when Mr. Bridger again called on the prisoner and inquired what was become of the wheat in question, when the prisoner declared that Franks and Co. had gone away largely in his debt, that he should never obtain from them the sum he had paid for the carriage, and that he knew nothing of what had become of the property.
Ground Truth: In consequence of the loss of the wheat further investigation ensued, and this continued until February last, when Mr. Bridger again called on the prisoner and inquired what was become of the wheat in question, when the prisoner declared that Franks and Co. had gone away largely in his debt, that he should never obtain from them the sum he had paid for the carriage, and that he knew nothing of what had become of the property.

OCR Text: Inquiries were then instituted' by Inspector Carpenter, ahighlyintelligent officer in the company's service, when it was ascertained that in April last the prisoner had directed a Mar. Strickland, a corn-factor, to sell the wheat fox him.
Ground Truth: Inquiries were then instituted by Inspector Carpenter, a highly intelligent officer in the company's service, when it was ascertained that in April last the prisoner had directed a Mr. Strickland, a corn-factor, to sell the wheat for him.

OCR Text: That he effected a sale to Messrs. Kidd, of Brighton, and that he hal received from Mr. Strickland a cheque for 8Sf., the amount of the purchase at the then market price.
Ground Truth: That he effected a sale to Messrs. Kidd, of Brighton, and that he had received from Mr. Strick land a cheque for 86l., the amount of the purchase at the then market price.

OCR Text: Such were the circumstances under which the railway company on public grounds instituted this prosecution.
Ground Truth: Such were the circumstances under which the railway company on public grounds instituted this prosecution.

OCR Text: The witnesses having been examined, Mr. Lilley addressed the jury for the prisoner, contending that his client was the victim of the pretended firm ot " Franks and Co.," who had gone away largely in his debt, and that he was a mere dupe.
Ground Truth: The witnesses having been examined, Mr. Lilley addressed the jury for the prisoner, contending that his client was the victim of the pretended firm of "Franks and Co.," who had gone away largely in his debt, and that he was a mere dupe.

OCR Text: The jury, after a brief consultation in their box, returned a verdict of " Guilty."
Ground Truth: The jury, after a brief consultation in their box, returned a verdict of "Guilty."

OCR Text: -The deputy-chairman therefore sentenced the prisoner to be imprisoned and kept to hard labour in the house of correction for six calendar months.
Ground Truth: -The deputy-chairman therefore sentenced the prisoner to be imprisoned and kept to hard labour in the house of correction for six calendar months.

Ground Truth: -Mr. Tyrwhitt: You thought yourself safe in advancing 5s. on articles worth 70l.

Ground Truth: -The witness answered that he should, as they would have been worth the money.

OCR Text: Mr. Tyrwhitt observed that if business was carried On in such a way, pawnbrokers' shops would become most dangerous places; in fact; nothing else but re- ceiving-houses.

OCR Text: -The witness said that if he had looked carefully at the earrings he would have seen that 'they were diamonds.
Ground Truth: -The witness said that if he had looked carefully at the earrings he would have seen that they were diamonds.

OCR Text: -r.. Tyrwbitt remarked that all he had to say was, that valuable articles were dealt with in these places in a very careless way.

Ground Truth: Mr. Mellish wished to say that he was quite ignorant of the pledging of the earrings.

Ground Truth: -She was then committed for trial, and her daughter was discharged.

OCR Text: FATAL ACCIDENT IN PICCADILLY.
Ground Truth: FATAL ACCIDENT IN PICCADILLY.

OCR Text: On Friday eSening, Mr. Bedford held an investiga tlon, at St. George's hospital, relative to the death of Charles Smith, a boy of sixteen years of age, who, having been led to view the demolition of the park railings on Tuesday evening last, losS his life under the following eircumstances:- H~enryWilliam Smith, 36, Raphael-street, K~nights. bridge-green, a coach painter, identified the body as that of bis son, who was a page boy in Orchard-street, Oxford-street.
Ground Truth: On Friday evening, Mr. Bedford held an investigation, at St. George's hospital, relative to the death of Charles Smith, a boy of sixteen years of age, who, having been led to view the demolition of the park railings on Tuesday evening last, lost his life under the following circumstances: -- Henry William Smith, 36, Raphael-street, Knights-bridge-green, a coach painter, identified the body as that of his son, who was a page boy in Orchard-street, Oxford-street.

OCR Text: Witness knew nothing of the accident.
Ground Truth: Witness knew nothing of the accident.

OCR Text: John Ward, a labourer, of 28, Francis-street, Chel- sea, said that about half-past nine on Tuesday night last, he was in Piccadilly, near the park-gates, there being but a small crowd there at the time.
Ground Truth: John Ward, a labourer, of 28, Francis-street, Chelsea, said that about half-past nine on Tuesday night last, he was in Piccadilly, near the park-gates, there being but a small crowd there at the time.

OCR Text: He saw the deceased behind a brougham, which was going abont five miles an bour.
Ground Truth: He saw the deceased behind a brougham, which was going about five miles an hour.

OCR Text: He was riding on theback of the carriage.
Ground Truth: He was riding on the back of the carriage.

OCR Text: Witness turned his head for a second, and on looking round he saw the boy between the wheel and the springs.
Ground Truth: Witness turned his head for a second, and on looking round he saw the boy between the wheel and the springs.

OCR Text: The carriage stopped on being called to.
Ground Truth: The carriage stopped on being called to.

OCR Text: Witness, with others5 eextricated the boy.
Ground Truth: Witness, with others, extricated the boy.

OCR Text: His legs were towfards the horse, one arm being betweaen the spokes, and his face between the springs.
Ground Truth: His legs were towards the horse, one arm being between the spokes, and his face between the springs.

OCR Text: BPr. Wm. Leigb, house-surgeon, deposed to seeing the deceasea when brought into the hospital.
Ground Truth: Mr. Wm. Leigh, house-surgeon, deposed to seeing the deceased when brought into the hospital.

OCR Text: There was a large scalp wound exposing the bone, a fracture of the skull, a comminuted fracture of the thigh, several bruises about the body, and no doubt internal injuries.
Ground Truth: There was a large scalp wound exposing the bone, a fracture of the skull, a comminuted fracture of the thigh, several bruises about the body, and no doubt internal injuries.

OCR Text: The wound and fractures were quite suffi- cient to cause death.
Ground Truth: The wound and fractures were quite sufficient to cause death.

OCR Text: The jury returned a verdict of " Accidental death."
Ground Truth: The jury returned a verdict of "Accidental death."

OCR Text: THIEVES AND RECEIVERS,
Ground Truth: THIEVES AND RECRIVERS.

OCR Text: vn Tcuesday, at tne Lambeth police-court, Thomas Shea, a simple-looking youth, was placed at the bar en a charge of stealing a leather bag containing some trifling articles, and George Evans and Louisa his wife, the keepers of a brothel at 18, Wellington-ter- race, Waterloo-road, were also charged with receiving the property with a guilty knowledge.
Ground Truth: On Tuesday, at the Lambeth police-court, Thomas Shea, a simple-looking youth, was placed at the bar on a charge of stealing a leather bag containing some trifling articles, and George Evans and Louisa his wife, the keepers of a brothel at 18, Wellington-terrace, Waterloo-road, were also charged with receiving the property with a guilty knowledge.

OCR Text: Police-con- stable Robinson, 48 P, said that on the previous night between ten and eleven o'clock he received information that a black bag containing some boots had been stolen from a cab in the front of the Weymouth Arms public-house, Newington, by a young fellow who had been left in charge of the vehicle.
Ground Truth: Police-constable Robinson, 48 P, said that on the previous night between ten and eleven o'clock he received information that a black bag containing some boots had been stolen from a cab in the front of the Weymouth Arms public-house, Newington, by a young fellow who had been left in charge of the vehicle.

OCR Text: He made inquiries, and found out that the thieq resided in No. 1, Nelson-court, Camberwell.
Ground Truth: He made inquiries, and found out that the thief resided in No. 1, Nelson-court, Camberwell.

OCR Text: Witness proceeded there, and found the prisoner Shea in bed.
Ground Truth: Witness proceeded there, and found the prisoner Shea in bed.

OCR Text: He aroused him, and asked for the bag he had taken from a cab in Weymouth-street.
Ground Truth: He aroused him, and asked for the bag he had taken from a cab in Weymouth-street.

OCR Text: The prisoner replied that he had sold it at a cigar shop in the Waterloo-road for 6s.
Ground Truth: The prisoner replied that he had sold it at a cigar shop in the Waterloo-road for 6s.

OCR Text: Witness, in com- pany with constable 345 P, proceeded with the lad to the Waterloo-road, and he there pointed out the house, 13, Wellington-terrace, as the place he had disposed of the bag.
Ground Truth: Witness, in company with constable 345 P, proceeded with the lad to the Waterloo-road, and he there pointed out the house, 13, Wellington-terrace, as the place he had disposed of the bag.

OCR Text: On knocking at the door, it was spened by the female prisoner.
Ground Truth: On knocking at the door, it was opened by the female prisoner.

OCR Text: In order to procure en entrance, and finding from the constable on the beat that it was a brothel, he (Robinson) asked if she had not in her house a young woman who had %bsconded from her parents.
Ground Truth: In order to procure an entrance, and finding from the constable on the beat that it was a brothel, he (Robinson) asked if she had not in her house a young woman who had absconded from her parents.

OCR Text: The prisoner replied that she had not, and that if he thought so he was at liberty to look over her house.
Ground Truth: The prisoner replied that she had not, and that if he thought so he was at liberty to look over her house.

OCR Text: She then admitted bim, his brother constable, and the prisoner Shea, sad on doing so, he asked her what she had done with the black bags he had purchased from Shea.
Ground Truth: She then admitted him, his brother constable, and the prisoner Shea, and on doing so, he asked her what she had done with the black bags he had purchased from Shea.

OCR Text: She replied that she had never seen the youth before, but said that two young men who had just gone over Waterloo-bridge had left a bag in her charge, and desired her to take care of it till they returned, and pointed to the bag, which was placed on a chair in the parlour.
Ground Truth: She replied that she had never seen the youth before, but said that two young men who had just gone over Waterloo-bridge had left a bag in her charge, and desired her to take care of it till they returned, and pointed to the bag, which was placed on a chair in the parlour.

OCR Text: Witness at once took possession of it and the prisoner.
Ground Truth: Witness at once took possession of it and the prisoner.

OCR Text: Shea said it was the same bag he had sold to the male prisoner for 6s., and which was paid for by his wife, and the articles which still remained in it exactly corresponded with those it contained when stolen.
Ground Truth: Shea said it was the same bag he had sold to the male prisoner for 6s., and which was paid for by his wife, and the articles which still remained in it exactly corresponded with those it contained when stolen.

OCR Text: He then told the prisoners he should take them into custody for receiving stolen goods.
Ground Truth: He then told the prisoners he should take them into custody for receiving stolen goods.

OCR Text: Un searching the house he found in different parts Df it, concealed, with portions of it under the beds, and between the beds and mattresses, nearly a vanload of valuable property.
Ground Truth: On searching the house, he found in different parts of it, concealed, with portions of it under the beds, and between the beds and mattresses, nearly a vanload of valuable property.

OCR Text: He also found 541. lOs. in gold, 51. in silver, and a 51. bank-note.
Ground Truth: He also found 54l. 10s. in gold, 5l. in silver, and a 5l. bank-note.

OCR Text: The pro- perty discovered consisted of rolls of cloth, rolls of Crpeting, a number of valuable shawls, ladies' silk dresses, a quanty of silk ties of different patterns, eases of straw hats, and also cases of bonnets of the same material, a number of watches, a quantity of tinga and valuable jewellery, teapots and teapot stands, a quantity of spoons and plate, and a large ches closely packed with splendidly-bound Bibles Sad Testaments, supposed to have been intended for exportation from a portion of the direction still ad- hering to the case containing the Bibles.
Ground Truth: The property discovered consisted of rolls of cloth, rolls of carpeting, a number of valuable shawls, ladies' silk dresses, a quanty of silk ties of different patterns, cases of straw hats, and also cases of bonnets of the same material, a number of watches, a quantity of rings and valuable jewellery, teapots and teapot stands, a quantity of spoons and plate, and a large chest closely packed with splendidly-bound Bibles and Testaments, supposed to have been intended for exportation from a portion of the direction still adhering to the case containing the Bibles.

OCR Text: It appears ts have been forwarded by rail to M~argate.
Ground Truth: It appears to have been forwarded by rail to Margate.

Ground Truth: -All the prisoners were remanded.

OCR Text: OUTRAGE ON, A MARRIED WOMAN.
Ground Truth: OUTRAGE ON A MARRIED WOMAN.

OCR Text: At the Gloucester assizes, on Monday, William Mustow was indicted for a rape on the 22nd of June last at Marshfield.
Ground Truth: At the Gloucester assizes, on Monday, William Mustow was indicted for a rape on the 22nd of June last at Marshfield.

OCR Text: The proseoutrix, Fanny Hill, was the wife of John Hill, shepherd, in the service of Mr. J. C. Fry, a large farmer in the parish of Marshfield, and the prisoner, who is a married man, was groom in the service of the same gentleman.
Ground Truth: The prosecutrix, Fanny Hill, was the wife of John Hill, shepherd, in the service of Mr. J. C. Fry, a large farmer in the parish of Marshfield, and the prisoner, who is a married man, was groom in the service of the same gentleman.

OCR Text: The prosecutrix and the prisoner lived in cottages adjoining one another, there being no other houses within a quarter of a mile.
Ground Truth: The prosecutrix and the prisoner lived in cottages adjoining one another, there being no other houses within a quarter of a mile.

OCR Text: The husband of the prosecutrix left home on Friday, June 22nd, and did not return that night.
Ground Truth: The husband of the prosecutrix left home on Friday, June 22nd, and did not return that night.

OCR Text: She went to bed at nine o'clock, and at twelve o'clock she was awakened by a rattling at her cottage door.
Ground Truth: She went to bed at nine o'clock, and at twelve o'clock she was awakened by a rattling at her cottage door.

OCR Text: She rose, looked out of the window and saw the prisoner 'below
Ground Truth: She rose, looked out of the window, and saw the prisoner below.

OCR Text: He asked her to come down and give kin some matches.
Ground Truth: He asked her to come down and give him some matches.

OCR Text: She got the matches and threw the box out of the window to him.
Ground Truth: She got the matches and threw the box out of the window to him.

OCR Text: He then went away.
Ground Truth: He then went away.

OCR Text: He shortly returned, called to her, and asked her to come down end warm some water.
Ground Truth: He shortly returned, called to her, and asked her to come down and warm some water.

OCR Text: This she declined to do, and thersu on he said he would break in and kill her if she did not.
Ground Truth: This she declined to do, and thereupon he said he would break in and kill her if she did not.

OCR Text: He then got on. the porch over the cottage door, sod placed hand' on the window sill of her bedroom, hut she struck him with a bed key and he dropped down.
Ground Truth: He then got on the porch over the cottage door, and placed his hand on the window sill of her bedroom, but she struck him with a bed key and he dropped down.

OCR Text: He then began breaking in the lower window with a stone.
Ground Truth: He then began breaking in the lower window with a stone.

OCR Text: She ran downstairs and rushed out of the house try- ing to get away.
Ground Truth: She ran downstairs and rushed out of the house trying to get away.

OCR Text: He ran after her, caught her, and dragged her into the house.
Ground Truth: He ran after her, caught her, and dragged her into the house.

OCR Text: After the struggle, in which she was severely injured and completely ex- hausted, be accomplished his purpose.
Ground Truth: After the struggle, in which she was severely injured and completely exhausted, be accomplished his purpose.

OCR Text: He put his hand over her mouth to prevent her screamingandsthe bit a niece-of flesh oit of one of his fingers.
Ground Truth: He put his hand over her mouth to prevent her screaming and she bit a piece of flesh out of one of his fingers.

OCR Text: He then left her and returned to his cottage.
Ground Truth: He then left her and returned to his cottage.

OCR Text: She, on hear. ing his door close, put on her shawl and went to her nearest neighbours, aroused thein, and related what had happened.
Ground Truth: She, on hearing his door close, put on her shawl and went to her nearest neighbours, aroused them, and related what had happened.

OCR Text: A witnessnam ed Ruth Gaisford said the prosecutrix had come to her house at about one o'clock in a state of exditement, with her hair down her back, and bleeding from a wound on her head, and as, they returned to her cottage she described the treatment sie had received.
Ground Truth: A witness named Ruth Gaisford said the prosecutrix had come to her house at about one o'clock in a state of excitement, with her hair down her back, and bleeding from a wound on her head, and as, they returned to her cottage she described the treatment she had received.

OCR Text: A man named Fry was called up, and he sent at once for the police, and went with &erjeant Midwinter to the prisoner's cottage.
Ground Truth: A man named Fry was called up, and he sent at once for the police, and went with Serjeant Midwinter to the prisoner's cottage.

OCR Text: They called to him, and as he did not open his door they burst it open and went upstairs, and found the prisoner sitting on his bed with his finger tied up and bleeding from a wound recently received.
Ground Truth: They called to him, and as he did not open his door they burst it open and went upstairs, and found the prisoner sitting on his bed with his finger tied up and bleeding from a wound recently received.

OCR Text: The prisoner was taken to the police-station, and on being charged, 'said it was all the - drink, and he wished he was in -

Ground Truth: The prisoner went to him on the 11th of that month and wrote a cheque for 31l. 15s. upon the Knights bridge branch of the London and County bank, and he proposed to pay his bill, and Mr. Jenner gave him the balance in five 5l. Bank of England notes.

OCR Text: HORRIBLE MURDER AT PENDLETON.
Ground Truth: HORRIBLE MURDER AT PENDLETON.

OCR Text: The body of a young woman was found in the Bolton and Manchester canal at Pendleton on Mon- day nsght, and a post-mortem examination of the body, which has since been made, seems to show that a brutal murder, has been committed, preceded by outrage of an extremely atrocious nature.
Ground Truth: The body of a young woman was found in the Bolton and Manchester canal at Pendleton on Monday night, and a post-mortem examination of the body, which has since been made, seems to show that a brutal murder has been committed, preceded by outrage of an extremely atrocious nature.

OCR Text: At an inquest opened at the King's Arms inn, Eccles, on Tuesday evening, the body was identified by two women, who had known deceased, as that of Kate Macdonald, a young woman who was employed ini the throstle departmnent of SirE. Armitage's mill at Pendleton about last Christmas.

OCR Text: Her mother was for several years housekeeper to Thomas Rudman, at Baoup.
Ground Truth: Her mother was for several years housekeeper to Thomas Rudman, at Bacup.

OCR Text: The body was seen floating in the canal near Strawberry-road bridge, Pendleton, on Monday night by Mrs. Sarah Broughton, of Pendleton.
Ground Truth: The body was seen floating in the canal near Strawberry-road bridge, Pendleton, on Monday night by Mrs. Sarah Broughton, of Pendleton.

Ground Truth: On Tuesday Mr. Davis, surgeon, made a post-mortem examination of the body.

Ground Truth: Externally there were two cuts on the face, one very deep; the upper part of one thigh was contused; and there was much effusion of blood beneath the skin about the lower part of the abdomen.

OCR Text: Both arms were fractured, one in two places; the right collar-bone was dislocated; and five or six of the upper ribs on both sides were broken, fragments of which penetrated the lungs and large vessels.
Ground Truth: Both arms were fractured, one in two places; the right collar-bone was dislocated; and five or six of the upper ribs on both sides were broken, fragments of which penetrated the lungs and large vessels.

OCR Text: The internal and external in- juries in the region of the abdomen were of a shock. ug character, and indicated the brutal n ature of the treatment to whioh the poor creature had been sub. jected before death.
Ground Truth: The internal and external injuries in the region of the abdomen were of a shocking character, and indicated the brutal nature of the treatment to which the poor creature had been subjected before death.

OCR Text: The surgeon was of upinion that the deceased was killed before being put into the w he fact that there was no water in the stomach, nor was the brain congealed.

Ground Truth: There was a considerable effusion of blood under the scalp on each side, but the brain was not injured.

Ground Truth: From appearances he thought the deceased could not have led a very immoral life.

Ground Truth: The police being unable to discover where or how the deceased had lived since about Christmas last, the inquest was adjourned to the 20th inst.

OCR Text: "Gii AGAINST THE POLIOC
Ground Truth: CHARGE AGAINST THE POLICE.

OCR Text: At the Westminster polae-court, on Friday, a man of gentlemanly appearance, speaking & very string German aceent, stated that he had been referred by tbe CommissIoner of Police to' a magistrate to make the following complaint against a Ipolieman, who had unjustly captured him upon a harge of which he knew nothing, and caused bis detention of two hours it a police-station.
Ground Truth: At the Westminster police-court, on Friday, a man of gentlemanly appearance, speaking a very strong German accent, stated that he had been referred by the Commissioner of Police to a magistrate to make the following complaint against a policeman, who had unjustly captured him upon a charge of which he knew nothing, and caused his detention of two hours at a police-station.

OCR Text: -Applloaitts account was, brieffy that he was talking with a lady at mid- day at Chelca In a public thoroughfare, when two policsmew came up, and one of them. said that he had a warrant against him, and he must accompany him to the station.
Ground Truth: -Applicant's account was, briefly, that he was talking with a lady at mid-day at Chelsea in a public thoroughfare, when two policemen came up, and one of them said that he had a warrant against him, and he must accompany him to the station.

OCR Text: Applicant expressed his extraordinary surprise, but one of the officers peralsted in taking, him through the streets to Pimlico station, where he was detained, as he was informed, upon some charge of burglary or some. thing in the country, until the arrival of some de- teotiee from somewhere, who said be was not the man who was wanted, and he was then told, he was at liberty.
Ground Truth: Applicant expressed his extraordinary surprise, but one of the officers persisted in taking him through the streets to Pimlico station, where he was detained, as he was informed, upon some charge of burglary or some- thing in the country, until the arrival of some detective from somewhere, who said he was not the man who was wanted, and he was then told, he was at liberty.

OCR Text: He wanted redress for the insult and wrong he had ,endured, and applied to 'the Com- missioner of Police, who, after some time occupied in investigating the matter, told him that his remedy wss before a polhce magis~trato, and be had accord- ingly waited upon his worship.
Ground Truth: He wanted redress for the insult and wrong he had endured, and applied to the Commissioner of Police, who, after some time occupied in investigating the matter, told him that his remedy was before a police magistrate, and he had accordingly waited upon his worship.

OCR Text: -Mr. Woolrch said as repreren'ted It was a case of great hardship and grievance, but it seamned to himn to ha the subjeet 0 an action for another court-it was a mistake.
Ground Truth: -Mr. Woolrych said as represented it was a case of great hardship and grievance, but it seemed to him to be the subject of an action for another court-it was a mistake.

OCR Text: - -Applieant repeated that be bad"been told his remedy was before a police menstrate.
Ground Truth: -Applicant repeated that he had been told his remedy was before a police magistrate.

OCR Text: Ile had suffered a gross injustice anid exposure before a'lady of his acquaintance and the public in the daytime, and he looked for the redress to which he was entitled.
Ground Truth: He had suffered a gross injustice and exposure before a lady of his acquaintance and the public in the daytime, and he looked for the redress to which he was entitled.

OCR Text: -Mr. Woolrych said he would make some Inquiries Into the matter if the applicant would comeagaic on Monday.
Ground Truth: -Mr.Woolrych said he would make some inquiries into the matter if the applicant would come again on Monday.

OCR Text: Dw4 i~dee, TT' ra. n wa*Jougha A ',o weind, R charged with attempting to murder his wife.
Ground Truth: Dr. Wades, a surgeon at Hanley, was brought up on remand, on Saturday, charged with attempting to murder his wife.

OCR Text: -Firs. Wades was Inattendance, andw she stasted that she had been married to prisoner four months, and had lived niihappily with him durig the greater part of that time'
