OCR Text: For about a month she had been leeping with theservantmaid, being sfraidto remain with herhusband, In consequence of his violence.
Ground Truth: For about a month she had been sleeping with the servant maid, being afraid to remain with her husband, in consequence of his violence.

OCR Text: On' Thursday he ordered her to make up a bed for herself in a toom opposite his own, but she told him 'that sbe'would not do so.
Ground Truth: On Thursday he ordered her to make up a bed for herself in a room opposite his own, but she told him that she would not do so.

OCR Text: They dined in silence. and she wdnt up to her dressing-room.
Ground Truth: They dined in silence, and she went up to her dressing-room.

OCR Text: Her husband followed her, and asked her if the bed was made.up, and sbeagaintold him she: wooldnot sleep there, upon which he said he would see who was the master.
Ground Truth: Her husband followed her, and asked her if the bed was made up, and she again told him she would not sleep there, upon which he said he would see who was the master.

OCR Text: He left the room, but presently returned with toe stickproduced,wvith whichhe struick her three or'four times.
Ground Truth: He left the room, but presently returned with the stick produced, with which he struck her three or four times.

Ground Truth: She went into another room, and prisoner followed her and struck her with his fist twice, making her eye black.

OCR Text: As she iturned toleave, the room he kicked her in the small of the back.
Ground Truth: As she turned to leave the room he kicked her in the small of the back.

OCR Text: She then left the house, and did not return until towards 10;' wh'en heir uslad attempted to strengld her.
Ground Truth: She then left the house, and did not return until towards 10, when her husband attempted to strangle her.

OCR Text: - In cross-examination Mrs. Wades said she was 34 years of age, but on being pressed she admitted she was older.
Ground Truth: -In cross-examination Mrs. Wades said she was 34 years of age, but on being pressed she admitted she was older.

OCR Text: She became acquainted with Dr. Wades through a Matrimonial Alliance association.
Ground Truth: She became acquainted with Dr. Wades through a Matrimonial Alliance association.

OCR Text: She had lived in Paris, and knew a gentleman named Edouard Leclerq.
Ground Truth: She had lived in Paris, and knew a gentleman named Edouard Leclerq.

OCR Text: She was not his wife, and had never passed as Madame Leclerq or Baxter.
Ground Truth: She was not his wife, and had never passed as Madame Leclerq or Baxter.

OCR Text: Upon being shown a card bearing-that name, she said it had been done by. M. Leclerq as a joke.
Ground Truth: Upon being shown a card bearing that name, she said it had been done by M. Leolerq as a joke.

OCR Text: She said that her marriage with the prisoner' had neverheen consumma~ted, but that was' not the reason she' quarrelled with the, defendant.
Ground Truth: She said that her marriage with the prisoner had never been consummated, but that was not the reason she quarrelled with the defendant.

OCR Text: She had told several persons that Dr. W~ades was incomnpetent. but it was only in 'self-defene.
Ground Truth: She had told several persons that Dr. Wades was incompetent, but it was only in self-defence.

OCR Text: She would never have mentioned it if he had only been kind to her.
Ground Truth: She would never have mentioned it if he had only been kind to her.

OCR Text: She refused to spend her private income on the household, and that was the cause of their disagreement.
Ground Truth: She refused to spend her private income on the house-hold, and that was the cause of their disagreement.

OCR Text: She denied that shewas in the habit of irritating him, or thateshe ever jeered hiini.
Ground Truth: She denied that she was in the habit of irritating him, or that she ever jeered him.

Ground Truth: –The evidence of Mrs. Wades was corroborated by the servant girl.

Ground Truth: –Medical evidence was called to show the serious nature of the injuries.

Ground Truth: –The Mayor said that a case of aggravated assault had been proved.

Ground Truth: Defendant must pay a fine of 20l., and find two sureties of 50l. to keep the peace for six months.

Ground Truth: –Ellen Cawfield, aged 24, pleaded "Guilty" to assaulting Sub-warder Elizabeth Porter, and occasioning her actual bodily harm.

OCR Text: -The prisoner was anI inmate of tide House of Correc- tion, having about three months longer to serve of a period of two yearst' imprisonment with hard labour, to which she was sentenced by this Court for felony on the 21st Februaiy, 1871.
Ground Truth: –The prisoner was an inmate of the House of Correction, having about three months longer to serve of a period of two years' imprisonment with hard labour, to which she was sentenced by this Court for felony on the 21st February, 1871.

OCR Text: On the 93rd of October last, for misconduct, she was ordered three days' bread and water, and in consequence of threats of violence she was put in a dark cell for a short time.
Ground Truth: On the 23rd of October last, for misconduct, she was ordered three days' bread and water, and in consequence of threats of violence she was put in a dark cell for a short time.

OCR Text: When she was directed to go to another cell she flatly refused, and two male warders had to carry her.
Ground Truth: When she was directed to go to another cell she flatly refused, and two male warders had to carry her.

OCR Text: She resisted so much on the way that Porter was asked to hold her hand, and the prisoner complained that she was too roughly handled.
Ground Truth: She resisted so much on the way that Porter was asked to hold her hand, and the prisoner complained that she was too roughly handled.

Ground Truth: She seems to have cherished resentment against Porter on this account, and on the 25th of October she made an excuse to get her cell door opened, and, darting down a corridor before she could be prevented, she dealt Porter a violent blow, which cut her lip, and felled her.

OCR Text: The prisonerthen returned quietly to hercell, and threatened that, if her time were prolonged, she veould do for the officer.
Ground Truth: The prisoner then returned quietly to her cell, and threatened that, if her time were prolonged, she would do for the officer.

Ground Truth: –Mrs. Howe proved that the prisoner had been three times convicted of assaults, and sentenced to terms of imprisonment–two months in September, 1865, six weeks in October, 1866, and one month in December, 1866.

Ground Truth: She said that the prisoner could behave herself very well, but had occasional outbursts of temper.

Ground Truth: –Sir W. Bodkin exhorted her to conduct herself properly and not attack those whose duty it was to enforce the rules of the prison, sentencing her to three months' further imprisonment for this offence.

OCR Text: I CHARGE OF FRAUDULENT TRADING.
Ground Truth: CHARGE OF FRAUDULENT TRADING.

OCR Text: On Friday Julius HeitzVp, of Englefield-road, wholesalejewelleranddiamond merchant, was re- examined at Bow-street police-court, charged with fraudulent trading under the Debtors act of 1869.
Ground Truth: On Friday Julius Heitzburg, of Englefield-road, wholesale jeweller and diamond merchant, was re-examined at Bow-street police-court, charged with fraudulent trading under the Debtors act of 1869.

OCR Text: At the previous examination it was proved that the prisoner commenced business in 1874 with a capital of about 1001., obtaining large quantities of jewel- lery from various wholesale houses by paying small deposits on the goods, and then pledging the goods to obtain more by further payme.ht of deposits.
Ground Truth: At the previous examination it was proved that the prisoner commenced business in 1874 with a capital of about 100l., obtaining large quantities of jewellery from various wholesale houses by paying small deposits on the goods, and then pledging the goods to obtain more by further payment of deposits.

OCR Text: According to the statement of Mr. Lewis, the pri. soner's " trading " was exclusively of this character up to the present year, when, in July last, he filed a petition in the Court of Bankruptcy, representing his unsecured debts to be 9,5021. 14i., andt his assets at about 6001. or 7001.

Ground Truth: The meeting desired also to record its solemn protest against the wars in Afghanistan and in South Africa, as utterly incapable of justification on any principle of justice or humanity.

Ground Truth: The last resolution passed by the meeting was as follows: --"That this meeting approves the course taken by the committee of the Peace society in sending a deputation to Berlin, to bring the question of arbitration before the Congress of the Great Powers, assembled in that city to negotiate the terms of peace; and while rejoicing that the principle embodied in the Protocol of Paris of 1856 has been re-affirmed, regrets that some further steps were not taken by that august body to recognise in a more distinct and authoritative form the duty of civilized nations to have recourse to peaceable means of settling their disputes, instead of appealing to the sword."

Osborne, retired wheelwright and cab proprietor, aged 62 years, and Mary Elizabeth Brenchley, aged 38, who had been living with the former as his wife.

Ground Truth: On Friday evening at about seven o'clock, in consequence of what I heard I went to his house in company with Constable M'Farren.

Ground Truth: In the kitchen we saw Miss Brenchley coming towards us.

Ground Truth: She pulled it aside, and said, "Look here."

Ground Truth: She was covered in blood, and we got her to a sofa, and called in two women.

Ground Truth: I asked where was Mr. Osborne, and she replied, "I don't know."

Ground Truth: He was dead upon the floor.

Ground Truth: There were no signs of a struggle, and I have no doubt whatever it was his own act.

Ground Truth: I next went into the back bedroom and there saw the signs of a most desperate struggle.

Ground Truth: We then returned downstairs and did what we could for the woman.

Ground Truth: They all went as far as Battersea, and after remaining there some time returned on the ebb tide.

OCR Text: Jobnrsoi was then lying in the stern of the boat, and the lad Jacobs was plying the oars, when-probably owing to the darkness-the boat ran foul of a number of barges, and began to over- turn.

Ground Truth: Directly he obtained possession the owner was surprised to see a notice posted up outside the shops, to the effect that they were to be let, and that a certain auctioneer would give all information.

Ground Truth: The replies also stated that Maxwell and Debenham had stood in the relation of tenant to the referees, and they were very sorry to lose them.

OCR Text: I TETHE ADVERTISEMENT DUTY.
Ground Truth: THE ADVERTISEMENT DUTY.

OCR Text: I,The following objections to the advertisement tax on newspapers were submitted to the Chancellor of the Exchequer by the deputation on Saturday: "1. Because it is a tax on knowledge, wad falls with partiality on an important portion of the press-the newspaper, magazine, and periodical. All other means of advertising escape the duty.
Ground Truth: The following objections to the advertisement tax on newspapers were submitted to the Chancellor of the Exchequer by the deputation on Saturday: "1. Because it is a tax on knowledge, and falls with partiality on an important portion of the press-the newspaper, magazine, and periodical. All other means of advertising escape the duty.

OCR Text: "2. It is an unjust tax. It cannot be equitably assessed or collected. The poor man pays Is. Ud. to advertise for employment.
Ground Truth: "2. It is an unjust tax. It cannot be equitably assessed or collected. The poor man pays 1s. 6d. to advertise for employment.

OCR Text: " 3. It falls heavily on particular classes of property, impounding to an important extent advertisements in journals. Il America, any man wke wishes to lend or to hire, to buy or to sell, announces his wish, without being subject to any duty, for is.
Ground Truth: "3. It falls heavily on particular classes of property, impounding to an important extent advertisements in journals. In America, any man who wishes to lend or to hire, to buy or to sell, announces his wish, without being subject to any duty, for 1s.

OCR Text: " 4. It acts most injuriously on literary works striving at cheapness. The cost of advertising sometimes amounts to more than the whole profit of author and publisher on works which are successful
Ground Truth: "4. It acts most injuriously on literary works striving at cheapness. The cost of advertising sometimes amounts to more than the whole profit of author and publisher on works which are successful.

OCR Text: " 5. It is a tax which goes far to fetter the free extension of the press, and prevents the eircula n of a sound and wholesome literature among working men In America there are 850 daily papers, in England there are only ten.
Ground Truth: "5. It is a tax which goes far to fetter the free extension of the press, and prevents the circulation of a sound and wholesome literature among working men. In America there are 850 daily papers, in England there are only ten.

OCR Text: "6. It creates'a monopoly. It is only the comparatively prosperous tredesman who can afford to advertise -the intelligent mechanic is excluded from newspaper publicity.
Ground Truth: "6. It creates a monopoly. It is only the comparatively prosperous tradesman who can afford to advertise –the intelligent mechanic is excluded from newspaper publicity.

OCR Text: "7 . It is one among many of the fiscal errors eommitted when the true principles of taxation were comparatively unknown. It involves the same principle by. which the lowest-priced Bohea is taxed at the same rate as the highest-priced Pekoe or Souchong-og which the miserable shirt-maker is made to pay a duty of about 300 per cent. on the original value of the article which she consumes, wehile the rich pay about eighty per cent. only.
Ground Truth: "7. It is one among many of the fiscal errors committed when the true principles of taxation were comparatively unknown. It involves the same principle by which the lowest-priced Bohea is taxed at the same rate as the highest-priced Pekoe or Souchong-on which the miserable shirt-maker is made to pay a duty of about 300 per cent. on the original value of the article which she consumes, while the rich pay about eighty per cent. only.

OCR Text: "8. It is a tax that 'should be repealed, because the public would derive the fall benefit of the repeal. In many cases a larger reduction than the duty would be made by newspaper proprietors.
Ground Truth: "8. It is a tax that should be repealed, because the public would derive the full benefit of the repeal. In many cases a larger reduction than the duty would be made by newspaper proprietors.

OCR Text: ' S. It is a tax which is easily and largely evaded. The blank icall, the advertising van (dangerously blocking up. the public thoroughfares), the omnibus, the railway carriage, the railway station, the street pavement, and many other modes of advertising, reduce the amount paid to Government to a comparativly small amount, and~leave its pressure exactly where it ij most severy felt, and where many grounds of public policy condemn it.
Ground Truth: "9. It is a tax which is easily and largely evaded. The blank wall, the advertising van (dangerously blocking up the public thoroughfares), the omnibus, the railway carriage, the railway station, the street pavement, and many other modes of advertising, reduce the amount paid to Government to a comparatively small amount, and leave its pressure exactly where it is most severely felt, and where many grounds of public policy condemn it.

OCR Text: " 10. In. a word-it is a great' impediment to trade, literature, and labour seeking a market, through publicty, and to the newspaper press for that reason; while the small amount of, revenue which it Yields-:ibout Me0,000o Per annuma-renders it altogether unwerthy oC retention, at a cost of'a tithe of the hardship and injustice which it inflicts "
Ground Truth: "10. In a word-it is a great impediment to trade, literature, and labour, seeking a market through publicity, and to the newspaper press for that reason; while the small amount of revenue which it yields-about 160,000l. per annum-renders it altogether unworthy of retention, at a cost of a tithe of the hardship and injustice which it inflicts."

OCR Text: SCARCITY OF CoAS. IN THS NoRTH.
Ground Truth: SCARCITY OF COALS IN THE NORTH.

OCR Text: -The late snowstorm having closed the roads in many districts in the north, occasioned a great scarcity of coals.
Ground Truth: -The late snowstorm having closed the roads in many districts in the north, occasioned a great scarcity of coals.

OCR Text: - In Elon, so much was the scarcity felt, that in some cases neighbours, to make their fuel last as long as possible, agreed to have but one fire between them, and go to each other's houses day about for cooking and warmth; and there was also a case where two women, the one with three children under her roof, and the other a pauper of some eighty years of age, who, with that quiet, unmurnturinS endurance of privation which is often so touchingly displayed by the Scottish poor, sat uncomplainingly for two whole days without fire in their dwellings.
Ground Truth: In Ellen, so much was the scarcity felt, that in some cases neighbours, to make their fuel last as long as possible, agreed to have but one fire between them, and go to each other's houses day about for cooking and warmth; and there was also a case where two women, the one with three children under her roof, and the other a pauper of some eighty years of age, who, with that quiet, unmurmuring endurance of privation which is often so touchingly displayed by the Scottish poor, sat uncomplainingly for two whole days without fire in their dwellings.

Ground Truth: -Edinburgh Witness.

OCR Text: | ThIE LAT CATAST4OPHE AT CLIrTON.,
Ground Truth: THE LATE CATASTROPHE AT CLIFTON.

OCR Text: he foig is the rdict ia this case:-We find that the deceased Thdmas Croston, lic'ard Simmons, and Geo re Barbour were killed on the 4th day of March initant, by the engine*o. Xo;1runming off the lineland upsetting near the Dixbnfold station, on the Manchester and Bolton railway, caused by the 'excessive speed- atwliicthit was driven by the deceased Thomas Croston, against whom we retina a verdict of "Manslaughter."
Ground Truth: The following is the verdict in this case: – We find that the deceased Thomas Croston, Richard Simmons, and George Barbour were killed on the 4th day of March instant, by the engine No. 13 running off the line and upsetting near the Dixon-fold station, on the Manchester and Bolton railway, caused by the excessive speed at which it was driven by the deceased Thomas Croston, against whom we return a verdict of "Manslaughter."

OCR Text: And we state that, althbough the rules of the company furnished to the guards and drivers limit the speed of express trains to 'thirty njiies an hour, this train has usually far exceeded that speed; and we think this could not so constantly have occurred without the knowledge and approbation of the directors of' the company.
Ground Truth: And we state that, although the rules of the company furnished to the guards and drivers limit the speed of express trains to thirty miles an hour, this train has usually far exceeded that speed; and we think this could not so constantly have occurred without the knowledge and approbation of the directors of the company.

OCR Text: We find also that the engine No. 13; from having only four vfwheels. and the length of time it -has been in use, was not a proper engine to attach to a train running thirty miles an hour, even on a railway in good and eff cient order; that the permanent way of this railway, as regards sleepers, chairs, and rails, in material 'and construction is generally very defective, and by no means safe; that the speed at which the points to branchlines are passed is highly dangerous; that the quick succession of trains on the lines from Manchester to Clifton junction with the East Lancashire company is also very dangerous; and that the general arrangements of the company as to the maintenance of way and managemeat of trains do not condce-to the safety of the pubhc; and we cannot too strongly condemn the management of the Lancashire and Yorkshire railway company on that portion of their line known as the Bolton and Preston district.
Ground Truth: We find also that the engine No. 13, from having only four wheels, and the length of time it has been in use, was not a proper engine to attach to a train running thirty miles an hour, even on a railway in good and efficient order; that the permanent way of this railway, as regards sleepers, chairs, and rails, in material and construction is generally very defective, and by no means safe; that the speed at which the points to branch lines are passed is highly dangerous; that the quick succession of trains on the lines from Manchester to Clifton junction with the East Lancashire company is also very dangerous; and that the general arrangements of the company as to the maintenance of way and management of trains do not conduce to the safety of the public; and we cannot too strongly condemn the management of the Lancashire and Yorkshire railway company on that portion of their line known as the Bolton and Preston district.

OCR Text: We are also of opinion that the speed at which express trains travel on all railways is so great that a stringent investigation should be instituted by the Board of Trade, ,as to the construction and present condition of the permanent way, engines, and carriages, as well as the working arrangements; and, we fear it will be found that the Lancashire and Yorkshire railway is not the only oie an which such a system of economy prevails as seriously to endanger the safety of the public."
Ground Truth: We are also of opinion that the speed at which express trains travel on all railways is so great that a stringent investigation should be instituted by the Board of Trade, as to the construction and present condition of the permanent way, engines, and carriages, as well as the working arrangements; and we fear it will be found that the Lancashire and Yorkshire railway is not the only one on which such a system of economy prevails as seriously to endanger the safety of the public."

OCR Text: WVe regret to have to state that another death (making five in the whole) has now resulted from this terrible accident-Mrs. Horrox having died in the infirmary about eleven o'clock on Friday night, from the effects of the shock upon her system.
Ground Truth: We regret to have to state that another death (making five in the whole) has now resulted from this terrible accident–Mrs. Horrox having died in the infirmary about eleven o'clock on Friday night, from the effects of the shock upon her system.

OCR Text: CHAR0.E OF ATTEMPT TO MURDER.,
Ground Truth: CHARGE OF ATTEMPT TO MURDER.

OCR Text: Ols Wednesday, a young man of respectable exterior, named Vivian O'Keefe, was charged at the Liverpool police-court with having attempted to murder a girl named Jane Riley, onk the 13th of March last, by discharging the contents of a loaded gun at her, in a shootijg gallery in Williamson-sqnare, near the Theatre Royal.
Ground Truth: On Wednesday, a young man of respectable exterior, named Vivian O'Keefe, was charged at the Liverpool police-court with having attempted to murder a girl named Jane Riley, on the 13th of March last, by discharging the contents of a loaded gun at her, in a shooting gallery in Williamson-square, near the Theatre Royal.

OCR Text: The hearing of the case had been deferred, in consequence of the inability of the prosecutrix to give evidence, owing to the precaeious state in which she has been since the occurrence.
Ground Truth: The hearing of the case had been deferred, in consequence of the inability of the prosecutrix to give evidence, owing to the precarious state in which she has been since the occurrence.

OCR Text: The prosecutrix, having been assisted into court, gave the following evidence.
Ground Truth: The prosecutrix, having been assisted into court, gave the following evidence.

OCR Text: She said: About twelve o'clock on the morning of the 13ih of March I went into a shooting gallery in Murray-street, Williamson-square.
Ground Truth: She said: About twelve o'clock on the morning of the 13th of March I went into a shooting gallery in Murray-street, Williamson-square.

OCR Text: I wanted to see the master.
Ground Truth: I wanted to see the master.

OCR Text: As I went in I saw the pri. soner standing on the steps.
Ground Truth: As I went in I saw the prisoner standing on the steps.

OCR Text: I beard himnsay to a friend, " I will have another shot, and then I will go home."
Ground Truth: I heard him say to a friend, "I will have another shot, and then I will go home."

OCR Text: He then followed me into the gallery.
Ground Truth: He then followed me into the gallery.

OCR Text: I went into a small room, called the snag, to see if the landlord was in.
Ground Truth: I went into a small room, called the snug, to see if the landlord was in.

OCR Text: Whilst I was there the prisoner came in and asked me to come to him.
Ground Truth: Whilst I was there the prisoner came in and asked me to come to him.

OCR Text: I did not speak to him.
Ground Truth: I did not speak to him.

OCR Text: He then smiled and took up a gun, and said he would shoot me.
Ground Truth: He then smiled and took up a gun, and said he would shoot me.

OCR Text: I thought he wras jolting, and said, "Oh, don't."
Ground Truth: I thought he was joking, and said, "Oh, don't."

OCR Text: I then tuned my back, and had hardly done so when the gun went off, and I felt a hal penetrate my shoulder.
Ground Truth: I then turned my back, and had hardly done so when the gun went off, and I felt a ball penetrate my shoulder.

OCR Text: I believe 1 was afterwards taken to the infirnCary.
Ground Truth: I believe I was afterwards taken to the infirmary.

OCR Text: The pri. soner appeared rather tipsy.
Ground Truth: The prisoner appeared rather tipsy.

OCR Text: Mary Ann M'Laren, wife of the man whe keeps the shooting-gallery, corroborated the prosecutrix's evidence, and added that she saw the prisoner present the gun at the proesecutrix, and heard him say to her, "I'll shoot you."
Ground Truth: Mary Ann MʻLaren, wife of the man who keeps the shooting-gallery, corroborated the prosecutrix's evidence, and added that she saw the prisoner present the gun at the prosecutrix, and heard him say to her, "I'll shoot you."

OCR Text: After saying so, the prisoner pulled up the ham. mer of the gun, and fired at her.
Ground Truth: After saying so, the prisoner pulled up the hammer of the gun, and fired at her.

OCR Text: Prosecutrix screamed out, saying she vwas shot, and blood began to flow from her shoulder.
Ground Truth: Prosecutrix screamed out, saying she was shot, and blood began to flow from her shoulder.

OCR Text: Witness then said to prisoner, "You have shot the woman, and I'm ruined."
Ground Truth: Witness then said to prisoner, "You have shot the woman, and I'm ruined."

OCR Text: He said nothing, but smiled, and left the place.
Ground Truth: He said nothing, but smiled, and left the place.

OCR Text: A police-officer deposed to taking the prisoner into custody at his lodgings in Islington-terrace the next. morning.
Ground Truth: A police-officer deposed to taking the prisoner into custody at his lodgings in Islington-terrace the next morning.

OCR Text: He denied all knowledge of the transaction, and said he did not remember having been in a shootinggallery the evening before.,
Ground Truth: He denied all knowledge of the transaction, and said he did not remember having been in a shooting-gallery the evening before.

OCR Text: The surgeon to the royal infirmary deposed to receiving the prosecutrix into the infirmary, as a patient, on the morning of the 13th oi March.
Ground Truth: The surgeon to the royal infirmary deposed to receiving the prosecutrix into the infirmary, as a patient, on the morning of the 13th of March.

OCR Text: On examining her, he found she had been shot in the shoulder.
Ground Truth: On examining her, he found she had been shot in the shoulder.

OCR Text: The charge hind entered the upper part of the shoulder, and passed into the spine.
Ground Truth: The charge had entered the upper part of the shoulder, and passed into the spine.

OCR Text: Had attended upon her since, and had not been able to extract the ball, but had traced it about four inches, and believed that it was at present lodged in the muscles of the back near the spine.
Ground Truth: Had attended upon her since, and had not been able to extract the ball, but had traced it about four inches, and believed that it was at present lodged in the muscles of the back near the spine.

OCR Text: He believed the prosecutrix to be at present out of danger.
Ground Truth: He believed the prosecutrix to be at present out of danger.

OCR Text: Mr. Snowbali, solicitor, appeared for the prisoner, and urged that there could not be a committal under the act of Parliament, as murder was not intended.
Ground Truth: Mr. Snowball, solicitor, appeared for the prisoner, and urged that there could not be a committal under the act of Parliament, as murder was not intended.

OCR Text: -The magistrate's clerk said that under the section of the act it would undoubtedly have been murder had the proseca. trix died; and after a few minutes' conversation the presiding magistrate said it was a very serious charge, and he felt bound to send it before a jury.
Ground Truth: – The magistrate's clerk said that under the section of the act it would undoubtedly have been murder had the prosecutrix died; and after a few minutes' conversation the presiding magistrate said it was a very serious charge, and he felt bound to send it before a jury.

OCR Text: The prisoner was then committed for trial at the assizes.
Ground Truth: The prisoner was then committed for trial at the assizes.

OCR Text: -Bail having been applied for, the prisoner's father came forward and said that ho was a housekeeper residing in Dblin, and connected with the press there.
Ground Truth: – Bail having been applied for, the prisoner's father came forward and said that he was a housekeeper residing in Dublin, and connected with the press there.

OCR Text: -The magistrates declined to accept his bail, and ordered the prisoner to find bail, himself in 100t., and two sureties resident in Liverpool in 01. each.
Ground Truth: The magistrates declined to accept his bail, and ordered the prisoner to find bail, himself in 100l., and two sureties resident in Liverpool in 50l, each.

OCR Text: ITHE MURDER IN SOMERSETSHIRE.,
Ground Truth: THE MURDER IN SOMERSETSHIRE.

OCR Text: At a place called Lype, in the parish of Catcombe, on the old Minehead and Danster-road, at the northern extremity of the Brendon-hill, and about six miles from Denster, lived a widow named Coles, with her son and daughter, the former about eighteen years of age, and the latter about eleven.
Ground Truth: At a place called Lype, in the parish of Cutcombe, on the old Minehead and Dunster-road, at the northern extremity of the Brendon-hill, and about six miles from Dunster, lived a widow named Coles, with her son and daughter, the former about eighteen years of age, and the latter about eleven.

OCR Text: It is a very lonely place, and the house in which they lived having been divided into two, the other was occupied by an aged woman named Norman.
Ground Truth: It is a very lonely place, and the house in which they lived having been divided into two, the other was occupied by an aged woman named Norman.

OCR Text: Near these houses was a barn, which had not been used for many years, and consequently it is in a very dilapidated state, the wooden floor being gone, and only some stone sleepers remaining.
Ground Truth: Near these houses was a barn, which had not been used for many years, and consequently it is in a very dilapidated state, the wooden floor being gone, and only some stone sleepers remaining.

OCR Text: The mother of the poor girl, Coles, the victim of this diabolical crime, left her house on the morning of Tnesday, the 8th inst., to go to work, and shortly after the son also went to his work at a neighbouring quarry, the deceased being left at home to attend to the affairs of the house.
Ground Truth: The mother of the poor girl, Coles, the victim of this diabolical crime, left her house on the morning of Tuesday, the 8th inst., to go to work, and shortly after the son also went to his work at a neighbouring quarry, the deceased being left at home to attend to the affairs of the house.

OCR Text: About ten o'clock the old woman, Mary Norman, who is eighty-five years ot age, in going along the passage through the houses, observed that the door of Cole's house was open, and saw the deceased sitting en one side of the fire-place, while a man named Bailey, who lived at a short distance, was seated on the other.
Ground Truth: About ten o'clock the old woman, Mary Norman, who is eighty-five years of age, in going along the passage through the houses, observed that the door of Cole's house was open, and saw the deceased sitting on one side of the fire-place, while a man named Bailey, who lived at a short distance, was seated on the other.

OCR Text: The deceased was not seen alive after that time.
Ground Truth: The deceased was not seen alive after that time.

OCR Text: About eleven o'clock a man named Sedgbeer, who was working opposite the entrance to Lype, saw Bailey advancing towards the place at which he (Sedgbeer) was in a hurried manner; and, on arriving at the spot where he stood, he observed that Bailey was labouring under excitement.
Ground Truth: About eleven o'clock a man named Sedgbeer, who was working opposite the entrance to Lype, saw Bailey advancing towards the place at which he (Sedgbeer) was in a hurried manner; and, on arriving at the spot where he stood, he observed that Bailey was labouring under excitement.

OCR Text: Bailey then proceeded to the quarry at which deceased's brother was working, and remained there, occasionaUy working for a short time, during which he partook of the dinner.
Ground Truth: Bailey then proceeded to the quarry at which deceased's brother was working, and remained there, occasionally working for a short time, during which he partook of the dinner.

OCR Text: At four o'clock Bailey left the quarry, and soon afterwards he called at the cottages at Lype, and inquired if "the old woman (Coles) or any of them" had returned.
Ground Truth: At four o'clock Bailey left the quarry, and soon afterwards he called at the cottages at Lype, and inquired if "the old woman (Coles) or any of them" had returned.

OCR Text: His mother replied in the nega, tive, and he then went away.
Ground Truth: His mother replied in the negative, and he then went away.

OCR Text: About seven o'clock the boy Coles returned, and, missing his sister, he went to meet his mother, who returned with him, and made inquiries for the poor girl at some neighboaring cottages.

OCR Text: | DARING ROBB RY AT A CHURCH.
Ground Truth: DARING ROBBERY AT A CHURCH.

OCR Text: On Monday morning, at an early hour, it was dis- covered that a most daring robbery had been committed in the vestry-room of the parish church of St. Giles. without, Cripplegate, by some expert thieves.
Ground Truth: On Monday morning, at an early hour, it was discovered that a most daring robbery had been committed in the vestry-room of the parish church of St. Giles- without, Cripplegate, by some expert thieves.

OCR Text: Late in the evening before (Sunday), the potman of Mr. Wiltshire, whose establishment adjoins the yard of the church at the back, nearly contiguous to the window of the vestry-room, heard something like a tapping at a pane of glass, and a sudden rustling as he passed his master's back door, before the hour of clos. ing.
Ground Truth: Late in the evening before (Sunday), the potman of Mr. Wiltshire, whose establishment adjoins the yard of the church at the back, nearly contiguous to the window of the vestry room, heard something like a tapping at a pane of glass, and a sudden rustling as he passed his master's back door, before the hour of closing.

OCR Text: Not taking any farther notice of this circum. stance, however, he made fast the back entrance, and with the family retired to rest.
Ground Truth: Not taking any further notice of this circumstance, however, he made fast the back entrance, and with the family retired to rest.

OCR Text: On Monday morning when he took down the back shutters, he found the vestry window in the churchyard broken, and the let. tice-work torn from its place.
Ground Truth: On Monday morning when he took down the back shutters, he found the vestry window in the churchyard broken, and the lattice-work torn from its place.

OCR Text: He immediately inform. ed his master, who sent for the churchwarden, Mr. John Scholes, of the White Hforse, Cripplepate, who having instantly proceeded to inspect the .premises, with the sexton, Mr. Johns, found that the vestry had been entered, and the master key of the iron safes ab- stracted from its usual plaee of keeping.
Ground Truth: He immediately informed his master, who sent for the churchwarden, Mr. John Scholes, of the White Horse, Cripplegate, who having instantly proceeded to inspect the premises, with the sexton, Mr. Johns, found that the vestry bad been entered, and the master key of the iron safes abstracted from its usual place of keeping.

OCR Text: The thief or thieves hadevidently enteredby theopening in thewin. daw, which they had caused by a most ingenious cut. ting away of the glass.
Ground Truth: The thief or thieves had evidently entered by the opening in the window, which they had caused by a most ingenious cutting away of the glass.

OCR Text: They had apparently carefully examined the safe and its contents, and succeeded in taking away the whole of the gold and silver there de- posited, which, however, in consequence of the heavy clearance of the amount of the former week's accumu- lation, was not a very considerable sum,
Ground Truth: They had apparently carefully examined the safe and its contents, and succeeded in taking away the whole of the gold and silver there deposited, which, however, in consequence of the heavy Clearance of the amount of the former week's accumulation, was not a very considerable sum.

OCR Text: Several of the drawers ia the vestry-room had been " prised," or forced with a lever, the marks of such an application of power being unmistafkeably evident.
Ground Truth: Several of the drawers in the vestry-room had been "prised," or forced with a lever, the marks of such an application of power being unmistakably evident.

OCR Text: The thieves hav- ing been defeated in obtaining any important amount of plunder, then forced the door from the vestry lead- ing into the church, and apparently attempted to force the contribution-box and the plate.chest, which resist. ed their efforts; for though the fastenings are violates, the contents remain secure.
Ground Truth: The thieves having been defeated in obtaining any important amount of plunder, then forced the door from the vestry leading into the church, and apparently attempted to force the contribution-box and the plate-chest, which resisted their efforts; for though the fastenings are violated, the contents remain secure.

OCR Text: Being thus foiled, it ap. pears that they then opened the closet containing the "tent," or "sacramental" wine.
Ground Truth: Being thus foiled, it appears that they then opened the closet containing the "tent," "or sacramental" wine.

OCR Text: This, it appears, was not according to their palate, as they left the bottle upon the floor, and the glass they had used, partially filled, standing beside it, but a small portion having been used from the bottle.
Ground Truth: This, it appears, was not according to their palate, as they left the bottle upon the floor, and the glass they had used, partially filled, standing beside it, but a small portion having been used from the bottle.

OCR Text: `[he closet containing the best wine was not touched, ner were some pounds in money in the sexton's drawer.
Ground Truth: The closet containing the best wine was not touched, nor were some pounds in money in the sexton's drawer.

OCR Text: The fellows having re- galed themselves, left the vestry in a state of confusion, leaving behind them the bags which contained the money they had stolen, and the iron safes apen.
Ground Truth: The fellows having regaled themselves, left the vestry in a state of confusion, leaving behind them the bags which contained the money they had stolen, and the iron safes open.

OCR Text: It is supposed that they obtained admission on Sunday even- ing to the churchyard, where one or more of them secreted themselves, and that, awaiting their opportu. nity, they effected the robbery about midnight, and subsequently decamped by the vicarage-bouse, which at the present time is not inhabited.
Ground Truth: It is supposed that they obtained admission on Sunday evening to the churchyard, where one or more of them secreted themselves, and that, awaiting their opportunity, they effected the robbery about midnight, and subsequently decamped by the vicarage-house, which at the present time is not inhabited.

OCR Text: MURDER AT PORTSMOUTH.
Ground Truth: MURDER AT PORTSMOUTH.

OCR Text: A very shocking occurrence took place late on Fd- day, the 22nd Feb., at No. 15, Kettering-place, Mile- end-road, Portsmouth.
Ground Truth: A very shocking occurrence took place late on Friday, the 22nd Feb., at No. 15, Kettering-place, Mile-end-road, Portsmouth.

OCR Text: The person whose life has O-A this occasion been destroyed, was Amelia Ansel, wife of William Ansell, a steward in the navy, and recently returned to this country in the Albion, 90, on board which ship he was captain's steward.
Ground Truth: The person whose life has on this occasion been destroyed, was Amelia Ansell, wife of William Ansell, a steward in the navy, and recently returned to this country in the Albion, 90, on board which ship he was captain's steward.

OCR Text: Ansell and the deceased had been out together on Friday afternoon, and she returned home earlier than he did.
Ground Truth: Ansell and the deceased had been out together on Friday afternoon, and she returned home earlier than he did.

OCR Text: Between ten and eleven o'clock a next-door neigrhbour heard Ansell and his wife quarrelling, and, soon after, the report of firearms.
Ground Truth: Between ten and eleven o'clock a next-door neighbour heard Ansell and his wife quarrelling, and, soon after, the report of firearms.

OCR Text: Some persons thereon went into the house and found the unfortunate woman lying on the floor quite senseless, and bleeding profusely from the temple.
Ground Truth: Some persons thereon went into the house and found the unfortunate woman lying on the floor quite senseless, and bleeding profusely from the temple.

OCR Text: Medical assistance was immediately procured, but death ensued in about an hour.,
Ground Truth: Medical assistance was immediately procured, but death ensued in about an hour.

OCR Text: The police being informed of the tragedy, at once took Ansell into custody.
Ground Truth: The police being informed of the tragedy, at once took Ansell into custody.

OCR Text: The latter told the constable that it was an accident.
Ground Truth: The latter told the constable that it was an accident.

OCR Text: He happened to have the pistol in his hand, and his wife touched the cock.
Ground Truth: He happened to have the pistol in his hand, and his wife touched the cock.

OCR Text: He did not knew at the time whether it was cooked or not, and that when it went off he was so .overwhelmed that he did not hear the report.
Ground Truth: He did not know at the time whether it was cocked or not, and that when it went off he was so overwhelmed that he did not hear the report.

OCR Text: When he recovered: himself he saw the blood gushing from her temple, and he put out his arms and said " Amelia, what have I done ?"
Ground Truth: When he recovered himself he saw the blood gushing from her temple, and he put out his arms and said, "Amelia, what have I done?"

OCR Text: He ran down stairs, h said, to send for medical aid.
Ground Truth: He ran down stairs, he said, to send for medical aid.

OCR Text: The ball entered just above the left temple, and lodged between the right jaw bone and the right ear.
Ground Truth: The ball entered just above the left temple, and lodged between the right jaw bone and the right ear.

OCR Text: But there were some of the fingers of the left hand shot away, as though the hand had been raised to protect the temple.
Ground Truth: But there were some of the fingers of the left hand shot away, as though the hand had been raised to protect the temple.

OCR Text: On Monday, the prisoner was examined before the borough magistrates.
Ground Truth: On Monday, the prisoner was examined before the borough magistrates.

OCR Text: The chief evidence bearing against the prisoner was that of the neighbours in the two houses adjoining'his residence in Kettering-street, Mile-end-road, Landport.
Ground Truth: The chief evidence bearing against the prisoner was that of the neighbours in the two houses adjoining his residence in Kettering-street, Mile-end-road, Landport.

OCR Text: The houses in thistreet are separated from each other merely by partitions of wood and plaster, and it appears that the residents of the houses adjoining the prisoner's heard distinctly a quarrel between him and his wife, and ultimately the exclamation from the latter, " Help, murder ! oh, give me time to make sny peace."
Ground Truth: The houses in this street are separated from each other merely by partitions of wood and plaster, and it appears that the residents of the houses adjoining the prisoner's heard distinctly a quarrel between him and his wife, and ultimately the exclamation from the latter, "Help, murder! oh, give me time to make my peace."

OCR Text: Irmediately aiter, the report of firearms was heard.
Ground Truth: Immediately after, the report of firearms was heard.

OCR Text: Th neighbours, on go- ing into the house, secured the prisoner, and then sent for medical assistance, but it did not avail even to pro- long life.
Ground Truth: The neighbours, ongoing into the house, secured the prisoner, and then sent for medical assistance, but it did not avail even to prolong life.

OCR Text: The police found a six-berrelled Colt's re- volver in the house, ,five barrels of which were loaded aid the other empty.
Ground Truth: The police found a six-barrelled Colt's revolver in the house, five barrels of which were loaded and the other empty.

OCR Text: We are proud to say that we know of no one in this metropolis who does not share with you in the just indignation which the speech of that senator provoked, and who 4ees not approve the instinct which prompted you to the punishment of one whose scurrility should deprive him of senatorial.protection, as it has already taken fomahun senatorial respect.
Ground Truth: We are proud to say that we know of no one in this metropolis who does not share with you in the just indignation which the speech of that senator provoked, and who does not approve the instinct which prompted you to the punishment of one whose scurrility should deprive him of senatorial protection, as it has already taken from him senatorial respect.

OCR Text: His incendiary and trea-* sonable orations are but the evidences of the length to 'which the toleration of irresponsible factionists will lead those whose love of country is lost in the desire to gratify selfish notoriety at any cost.
Ground Truth: His incendiary and treasonable orations are but the evidences of the length to which the toleration of irresponsible factionists will lead those whose love of country is lost in the desire to gratify selfish notoriety at any cost.

OCR Text: Your rebuke, it is to be hoped, will satisfy such men that there are con- soquezces beside those provided by law for which they must prepare.
Ground Truth: Your rebuke, it is to be hoped, will satisfy such men that there are consequences beside those provided by law for which they must prepare.

OCR Text: It is not because this senator has been 'pleased to advocate doctrines the practical adoption of 'which would develope, as the least of its evils, a dis- solution of the union, nor because that in doing so he has exhibited a tempe so selfish in its tendencies and indecent in its development s' to causeevery true lover of his country to regret that hesitainthe senate csni. ber of the union; but it is because lie has dared, in contravention of all propriety, and with studied con- tempt of all decorun, to introduce our state in his de- bate in terms so gross and insulting that no son of hers could have remained unmoved.
Ground Truth: It is not because this senator has been pleased to advocate doctrines the practical adoption of which would develop, as the least of its evils, a dissolution of the union, nor because that in doing so he has exhibited a temper so selfish in its tendencies and indecent in its development as to cause every true lover of his country to regret that he sits in the senate chamber of the union; but it is because he has dared, in contravention of all propriety, and with studied contempt of all decorum, to introduce our state in his debate in terms so gross and insulting that no son of here could have remained unmoved.

OCR Text: In your case addi- onal aggravation was found in the fact that the terms in which your venerable relative was referred to made it your duty, in his absence, to punish the r.

Ground Truth: You have applied a blow to his back.

Ground Truth: His submission to your blows has now qualified him for the closest companionship with a degraded class.

Ground Truth: The witness lost all trace of his sister and the defendant and returned home.

Ground Truth: Witness and his brother begged their sister to accompany them home, but the defendant exclaimed, "Alice, don't go."

OCR Text: The article was headed " The London MusichaUl," and commenced-" A London music-hall is commossly looked upon as a public-house upon a very extended. scale, but it is more than this. Ground Truth: The article was headed "The London Musichall," and commenced--"A London music-hall is commonly looked upon as a public-house upon a very extended scale, but it is more than this. Here we perceive every phase of indolence, the parent of vice, flaunting its dirt and wretchedness, its shamelessness, and its filth, whether it be among the occupants of the gallery, or the better dressed but scarcely more refined habitues of the stalls."

OCR Text: Mr Besley wenton to read the article through, which in effect said that the habiftus of the place " treated " the manager.
Ground Truth: Mr. Besley went on to read the article through, which in effect said that the habitués of the place "treated" the manager.

OCR Text: They were accustomed to talk," horsey," being largeiy composed of billiard sharps, horse vopers, 4ind welchersa

OCR Text: The performance was not of a decent charaeter.
Ground Truth: The performance was not of a decent character.

Ground Truth: The proprietor drank with everybody, but from a tap of his own.

Ground Truth: Mr. John Richards, clerk to the solicitor, said that on the 11th inst. he went to the defendant, who said that he was the author of the article on "The London Music-hall," but that it had been greatly altered by the editor.

H. L. Raphael and Co., of 25, Throgmorton-street; he was also charged with having feloniously received 20,000l. worth of Peruvian bonds, the property of Messrs. Lewis Cohen and Co., of 31, Throgmorton-street.

Ground Truth: This was at twenty minutes to one o'clock.

Ground Truth: I was introduced to him as Mr. Frost, from Brighton.

Ground Truth: We had something to drink in the public-house, which I paid for, and Carr called for three cigars.

Ground Truth: He then said, "You know our business?" and I replied, "Yes."

Ground Truth: He then asked me if I had got the "flimsies," and I showed him the bank-notes.

OCR Text: We afterwards left the public- house, and the prisoner observing, " I do business with one person," he spoke to the third man, and I and the prisoner then drove to the Great Northern hotel, King's-cross.
Ground Truth: We afterwards left the public-house, and the prisoner observing, "I do business with one person," he spoke to the third man, and I and the prisoner then drove to the Great Northern hotel, King's-cross.

Ground Truth: He took me to a room, No. 78, on the fourth floor, and bolting the door he produced a black bag, from which he took the bonds produced, observing, "There they are."

Ground Truth: I then tied them up and said, "You must consider yourself in custody; I am a detective from the City, and these bonds are stolen."

Ground Truth: I repeated what I had said, adding, "You may as well do the thing quietly."

OCR Text: From the evidence produced, it appeared that, a few days since, Spratley was hired by a lady and gentleman who alighted at the Castle, from Williams's Reading coach, to drive them to Clapham.

OCR Text: Quantill, after his return, gave Spratley only X24, saying he should keep the other for his trouble.
Ground Truth: Quantill, after his return, gave Spratley only £24, saying he should keep the other for his trouble.

OCR Text: Spratley, not much pleased with his conduct, gave 21 sovereigns to the prisoner, Disforges, to keep for him, and on his asking him for them on Saturday, he refused to return him more than: 14.
Ground Truth: Spratley, not much pleased with his conduct, gave 21 sovereigns to the prisoner, Disforges, to keep for him, and on his asking him for them on Saturday, he refused to return him more than £14.

OCR Text: Spratley accordingly applied to the magistrates on the same dai, for a summons against his fellow-prisoners.
Ground Truth: Spratley accordingly applied to the magistrates on the same day for a summons against his fellow-prisoners.

OCR Text: When the magistrates became acquainted with the above circumstances, they ordered all three to be taken into custody.
Ground Truth: When the magistrates became acquainted with the above circumstances, they ordered all three to be taken into custody.

Ground Truth: The Driver of Williams's coach remembered bringing a lady and gentleman to the Castle, Brentford, but he did not know who they were, as they came to the coach in a post-chaise.

Ground Truth: -Yesterday, Mary Ann Turner and Elizabeth Hayley, who described themselves as "unfortunate girls," were brought before Mr. Hoskins, charged with the following disorderly conduct: - It appeared from the evidence, that on the previous night, as police-constable 123 S was on duty, he heard a great disturbance in the Hampstead-road, and on going to the spot found the prisoners, who were both intoxicated, in the act of deciding a quarrel by a pugilistic contest, surrounded by a mob of low characters, and divested of their bonnets, caps, and shawls; the prisoner Turner was the more violent of the two, and before the disgraceful scene was put an end to, she had actually torn out a considerable portion of her antagonists hair by the roots; they were ultimately conveyed away to the station-house in Albany-street, but had not been confined there above an hour, before one of the constables present detected Turner in the very act of tying round her throat a silk-handkerchief, one end of which was securely fastened to the iron window-bar of the cell; she at length became more calm, and promised not to repeat the attempt: the constable then closed the door, and shortly afterwards fancied that he heard a kind of gurgling noise, which again led him to the place of her confinement, on entering which, he discovered her suspended from the same place by her garters, quite black in the face, and apparently in the agonies of death; he immediately drew from his pocket a clasp-knife, with which he cut down the unhappy and dissolute girl, who after the lapse of sometime recovered, and expressed the greatest sorrow and contrition for the attempt she had made upon her life.

Ground Truth: Mr. HOSKINS having ascertained that the prisoners had not been charged with misconduct at any former period, discharged them both with a suitable admonition, at the same time telling them, that for a second offence they would be sent to the House of Correction.

OCR Text: SOUTH DE 'ON ELECTION.
Ground Truth: SOUTH DEVON ELECTION.

OCR Text: To THE EDITOR oF mTO MORNING CHRONICLE.
Ground Truth: TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING CHRONICLE.

OCR Text: - ia.-I yesterday recorded my tote at hingsbridge In favour of Lord John Russell, end soon afterwards took my departurrefor London.
Ground Truth: Era-I yesterday recorded my vote at Kingsbridge in favour of Lord John Russell, and soon afterwards took my departure for London.

OCR Text: From what I have seen and heard, I have no doubt but that the Tory candidate will prove succeesful.
Ground Truth: From what I have seen and heard, I have no doubt but that the Tory candidate will prove successful.

OCR Text: Throughout the county the walls wete marked with No Russell, " Nto Popery," and slmilaf epithets; and bills, charging Lord John with almost everytbing that is evil, were extensively circulated.
Ground Truth: Throughout the county the walls were marked with "No Russell," "No Popery," and similar epithets; and bills, charging Lord John with almost everything that is evil, were extensively circulated.

OCR Text: Reports were also afloat calculated to frighten the electors of South Devon, and Induce them to believe that Lord John would establih Popery, with all its train of persecuting horrors; but this bugbea? to frighten the good people of South Devon is nothing compared to the tyranny exercised by the Tory landholders and parish priests over theIr tenans and parishioners.
Ground Truth: Reports were also afloat calculated to frighten the electors of South Devon, and induce them to believe that Lord John would establish Popery, with all its train of persecuting horrors; but this bugbear to frighten the good people of South Devon is nothing compared to the tyranny exercised by the Tory landholders and parish priests over their tenants and parishioners.

OCR Text: It Is notorious that multitudes of landlords gave their tenants the optIon of voting contrary to conscience, or the sacrifice of their families by quitting their estates.
Ground Truth: It is notorious that multitudes of landlords gave their tenants the option of voting contrary to conscience, or the sacrifice of their families by quitting their estates.

OCR Text: Hun- dreds, it Is supposed, yielded to the claims of their fami- lics; and large numbers, known to be decided Liberals, voted for the Tory candidate to save their families from ruin,
Ground Truth: Hundreds, it is supposed, yielded to the claims of their families; and large numbers, known to be decided Liberals, voted for the Tory candidate to save their families from ruin.

OCR Text: - A farmer, with tears In his eyes, came to solicit my ad- vice under these circumstances.
Ground Truth: A farmer, with tears in his eyes, came to solicit my advice under these circumstances.

OCR Text: I hesitated as to the advice I should give, when he paused, and then exclaimed in an agony of desperation, " I am determined to do my duty, and await the consequences."
Ground Truth: I hesitated as to the advice I should give, when he paused, and then exclaimed in an agony of desperation, "I am determined to do my duty, and await the consequences."

OCR Text: I could not but ad- mire his patriotism.
Ground Truth: I could not but admire his patriotism.

OCR Text: Is It right that men and their families should be placed in this dilemrnma?
Ground Truth: Is it right that men and their families should be placed in this dilemma?

OCR Text: Ihave ver beer opposed to the ballot, but unless some other remedy can be found, from what the last few days have shown me, I am convinced of Its utility.
Ground Truth: I have ever been opposed to the ballot, but unless some other remedy can be found, from what the last few days have shown me, I am convinced of Its utility.

OCR Text: I have seen flocks of poor tenants driven to the polling pIlaee like negro slaves to the market; the squire and p-rish priest in their carriages, leading; the poor tenants of the parish following; and livery servants bringing up the cavalcade, like whippers-in, to see that none escaped.
Ground Truth: I have seen flocks of poor tenants driven to the polling place like negro slaves to the market; the squire and parish priest in their carriages, leading; the poor tenants of the parish following; and livery servants bringing up the cavalcade, like whippers-in, to see that none escaped.

OCR Text: Is this freedom of election?
Ground Truth: Is this freedom of election?

OCR Text: Can it be endured much longer?
Ground Truth: Can it be endured much longer?

OCR Text: Either let the country be given up to the aris- tocracy aind parsons, or protect the tenantsfrom worse than slavery.
Ground Truth: Either let the country be given up to the aristocracy and parsons, or protect the tenants from worse than slavery.

OCR Text: I hope the defeat in Devon will produce a remedy for this horrible evil
Ground Truth: I hope the defeat in Devon will produce a remedy for this horrible evil.

OCR Text: -I am, Sir, yours respectfully, Eastcheap, May 5.
Ground Truth: -I am, Sir, yours respectfully, Eastcheap, May 5.
